DIV1.P: THE SECOND PART OF THE HONEST VVHORE, VVITH THE HVMORS of the Patient Man, the Impatient Wife: the Honest Whore, perswaded by strong Arguments to turne Curtizan againe: her braue refuting those Arguments.
And lastly, the Comicall Passages of an Italian Bridewell, where the Scaene ends.
LONDON, Printed by Elizabeth All-de, for Nathaniel Butter. An. Dom. 1630.

SP.STAGE: Enter at one doore Beraldo, Carolo, Fontinell, Astolfo, with Seruingmen, or Pages attending on them; at another doore enter Lodouico, meeting them.

SP.SPEAKER: Lodouico.
SP.L: GOod day, Gallants.

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes.
SP.L: Good morrow, sweet Lodouico.

SP.SPEAKER: Lodo.
SP.L: How doest thou Carolo.

SP.SPEAKER: Carolo.
SP.P: Faith, as Physicions doe in a Plague, see the World sicke, and am well my selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Fontinell.
SP.L: Here's a sweet morning, Gentlemen.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: Oh, a morning to tempt Ioue frō his Ningle Ganimed, which is but to giue Dary Wenches greene gownes as they are going a milking; what, is thy Lord stirring yet?

SP.SPEAKER: Astolfo.
SP.L: Yes, he will not be horst this houre, sure.

SP.SPEAKER: Bercaldo.
SP.P: My Lady sweares he shall, for she longs to bee at Court.

SP.SPEAKER: Carolo.
SP.P: Oh, wee shall ride switch and spurre, would we were there once.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: How now, is thy Lord ready?

SP.SPEAKER: Bryan.
SP.P: No so crees sa mee, my Lady will haue some little Tyng in her pelly first.

SP.SPEAKER: Caro.
SP.L: Oh, then they'le to breakefast.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: Footman, does my Lord ride y'th Coach with my Lady, or on horsebacke?

SP.SPEAKER: Bry.
SP.P: No foot la, my Lady will haue me Lord sheet wid her, my Lord will sheet in de one side, and my Lady sheet in de toder side.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: My Lady sheet in de toder side: did you euer here a Rascall talke so like a Pagan? Is't not strange that a fellow of his starre, should bee seene here so long in Italy, yet speake so from a Christian?
SP.STAGE: Enter Anthonio, Georgio, a poore Scholler.

SP.SPEAKER: Aslol.
SP.P: An Irishman in Italy! that so strange! why, the na∣tion haue running heads.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: Nay Carolo, this is more strange, I ha bin in France, theres few of them: Mary, England they count a warme chimny corner, and there they swarme like Crickets to the creuice of a Brew-house; but Sir, in England I haue noted one thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes.
SP.L: What's that, what's that of England?

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Mary this Sir, what's he yonder?

SP.SPEAKER: Bert.
SP.L: A poore fellow would speake with my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: In England, Sir, troth I euer laugh when I thinke on't: to see a whole Nation should be mark't i'th forehead, as a man may say, with one Iron: why Sir, there all Coster∣mongers are Irishmen.

SP.SPEAKER: Caro.
SP.P: Oh, that's to show their Antiquity, as comming from Eue, who was an Apple-wife, and they take after the Mother.

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes.
SP.L: Good, good, ha, ha.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: Why then, should all your Chimny-sweepers like∣wise be Irishmen? answer that now, come, your wit.

SP.SPEAKER: Caro.
SP.P: Faith, that's soone answered, for S. Patricke you know keepes Purgatory, hee makes the fire, and his Country-men could doe nothing, if they cannot sweepe the Chimnies.

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes.
SP.L: Good agen.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: Then, Sir, haue you many of them (like this fellow) (especially those of his haire) Footmen to Noblemen and o∣thers, and the Knaues are very faithfull where they loue, by my faith very proper men many of them, and as actiue as the cloudes, whirre, hah.

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes.
SP.L: Are they so?

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: And stout! exceeding stout; Why, I warrant, this precious wild Villaine, if hee were put to't, would fight more desperately then sixteene Dunkerkes.

SP.SPEAKER: Asto.
SP.L: The women they say are very faire.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: No, no, our Country Bona Robaes▪ oh! are the su∣grest delicious Rogues.

SP.SPEAKER: Asto.
SP.L: Oh, looke, he has a feeling of them.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: Not I, I protest, there's a saying when they com∣mend Nations: It goes, the Irishman for his hand, Welsh∣man for a leg, the Englishman for a face, the Dutchman for beard.

SP.SPEAKER: Fron.
SP.L: I faith, they may make swabbers of them.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: The Spaniard, let me see, for a little foot (I take it) the
Frenchman, what a pox hath he? and so of the rest.
Are they at breakfast yet? come walke.

SP.SPEAKER: Ast.
SP.L: This Lodouico, is a notable tounged fellow.

SP.SPEAKER: Fron.
SP.L: Discourses well.

SP.SPEAKER: Berc.
SP.L: And a very honest Gentleman.

SP.SPEAKER: Asto.
SP.L: Oh! hee's well valued by my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Fron.
SP.L: How now, how now, what's she?

SP.SPEAKER: Bert.
SP.L: Let's make towards her.

SP.SPEAKER: Bella.
SP.L: Will it be long, sir, ere my Lord come forth?

SP.SPEAKER: Ast.
SP.L: Would you speake with my Lord?

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P:
How now, what's this, a Nurses Bill? hath any here
got thee with child, and now will not keepe it?

SP.SPEAKER: Bolla.
SP.L: No sir, my businesse is vnto my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: Hee's about his owne wife now, hee'le hardly dis∣patch two causes in a morning.

SP.SPEAKER: Asto.
SP.P: No matter what he saies, faire Lady, hee's a Knight, there's no hold to be taken at his words.

SP.SPEAKER: Fro.
SP.L: My Lord will passe this way presently.

SP.SPEAKER: Bert.
SP.L: A pretty plumpe Rogue.

SP.SPEAKER: Ast.
SP.L: A good lusty bouncing baggage.

SP.SPEAKER: Bert.
SP.L: Doe you know her?

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: A pox on her, I was sure her name was in my Table∣booke once, I know not of what cut her dye is now, but she has beene more common then Tobacco: this is she that had the name of the Honest Whore.

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes.
SP.L: Is this she?

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: This is the Blackamore that by washing was turned white: this is the Birding Peece new scowred: this is shee that (if any of her religion can be saued) was saued by my Lord Hipolito.

SP.SPEAKER: Asto.
SP.L: She has beene a goodly creature.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: She has bin! that's the Epitaph of all Whores, I'm well acquainted with the poore Gentleman her Husband, Lord! what fortunes that man has ouerreached? She knowes not me, yet I haue beene in her company, I scarce know her, for the beauty of her cheeke hath (like the Moone) suffred strange Eclipses since I beheld it: but women are like Med∣lars (no sooner ripe but rotten.)
SP.L: A woman last was made, but is spent first,
Yet man is oft proued, in performance worst.

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes.
SP.L: My Lord is come.
SP.STAGE: Enter Hypolito, Infaeliche, and two waiting women.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: We ha wasted halfe this morning: morrow Lodouico.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Morrow Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Let's away to Horse.

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes.
SP.L: I, I to Horse, to Horse.

SP.SPEAKER: Bela.
SP.P: I doe beseech your Lordship, let your eye read e're this wretched Paper.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: I'm in hast, pray the good womā take some apter time.

SP.SPEAKER: Insae.
SP.L: Good Woman doe.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Oh las! it does concerne a poore mans life.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.P: Life! sweet heart? Seat your selfe, Il'e but read this and come.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: What stockings haue you put on this morning, Ma∣dam? if they be not yellow, change them; that paper is a Letter from some Wench to your Husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Infae
SP.L: Oh sir, that cannot make me iealous.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Your busines, sir, to me?

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Yes my good Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Presently sir; are you Mathaeos wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Bela.
SP.L: That most vnfortunate woman.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: I'm sorry these stormes are fallē on him, I loue Mathaeo.
And any good shall doe him, hee and I.
Haue sealed two bonds of friendship, which are strong
In me, how euer Fortune does him wrong;
He speakes here hee's condemned. Is't so?

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Too true.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.P: What was he whom he killed? Oh, his name's here; old lacomo, sonne to the Florentine lacomo, a dog, that to meet profit, would to the very eyelids wade in blood of his owne children. Tell Mathaeo, the Duke my father hardly shall deny his signed pardon, 'twas faire fight, yes if rumors tongue goe true, so writes he here.
SP.L: To morrow morning I returne from Court;
Pray be you here then. Ile haue done sir straight:
But in troth say, are you Mathaeos wife?
You haue forgot me.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: No, my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Your Turner,
That made you smooth to run an euen byas,
You know I loued you when your very soule
Was full of discord: art not a good wench still?

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Vmph, whē I had lost my way to heauen, you shewedit:
I was new borne that day.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P:
S'foot, my Lord, your Lady askes if you haue not left
your Wench yet? When you get in once, you neuer haue done: come, come, come, pay your old score, and send her packing, come.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Ride softly on before, Ile oretake you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: Your Lady sweares she'll haue no riding on before, without ye.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Prethee good Lodonico.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: My Lord pray hasten.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.P: I come: to morrow let me see you, fare you well: commend me to Mathaeo: pray one word more: Does not your father liue about the Court?

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: I thinke he does, but such rude spots of shame
Stick on my cheeke, that he scarce knowes my name.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Orlando Friscabaldo, Is't not?

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Yes my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: What does he for you?

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: All he should: when Children
From duty start, Parents from loue may swarue.
He nothing does: for nothing I deserue.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.P: Shall I ioyne him vnto you, and restore you to wonted grace?

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: It is impossible.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: It shall be put to tryall: fare you well:
The face I would not looke on I sure then 'twas rare,
When in despight of griefe, 'tis still thus faire.
Now, sir, your businesse with me.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.P: I am bold to expresse my loue and duty to your Lordship in these few leaues.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: A Booke!

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Yes my good Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Are you a Scholler?

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Yes, my Lord, a poore one.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Sir, you honor me.
Kings may be Schollers Patrons, but faith tell me,
To how many hands besides hath this bird flowne,
How many partners share with me?

SP.SPEAKER: An.
SP.L: Not one in troth, not one: your name I held more deare,
I'm not (my Lord) of that low Character.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Your name I pray?

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Of Millan?

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Yes my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Ile borrow leaue
To read you o're, and then we'll talke: till then
Drinke vp this gold, good wits should loue good wine,
This of your loues, the earnest that of mine.
How now, sir, where's your Lady, not gone yet?

SP.SPEAKER: Bryan.
SP.P: I fart di Lady is runne away from dee, a mighty deale of ground, she sent me backe for dine owne sweet face, I pray dee come my Lord away, wut tow goe now?

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Is the Coach gone?
Saddle my Horse the sorrell.

SP.SPEAKER: Bryan.
SP.P: A pox a de Horses nose, he is a lowsy rascally fellow, when I came to gird his belly, his scuruy guts rum∣bled, di Horse farted in my face, and dow knowest, an Irish∣man cannot abide a fart, but I haue saddled de Hobby-horse, di fine Hobby is ready, I pray dee my good sweet Lord, wit tow goe now, and I will-runne to de Deuill before dee?

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Well, sir, I pray lets see you Master Scholler.

SP.SPEAKER: Bry.
SP.L: Come I pray dee, wut come sweet face? Goe.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Gods so, Gentlemen, what doe we forget?

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes.
SP.L: What?

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: Are not we all enioyned as this day, Thursday is't not? I as that day to be at the Linnen-drapers house at din∣ner?

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.L: Signior Candido, the patient man.

SP.SPEAKER: Asto.
SP.L: Afore Ioue, true, vpon this day hee's married.

SP.SPEAKER: Berc.
SP.P: I wonder, that being so stung with a Waspe be∣fore, he dares venture againe to come about the eaues a∣mongst Bees.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P:
Oh 'tis rare sucking a sweet Hony-combe; pray Heauen his old wife be buried deepe enough, that she rise
not vp to call for her daunce, the poore Fidlers Instruments would cracke for it, shee'd tickle them: at any hand lets try what mettle is in his new Bride, if there be none, we'll put in some; troth it's a very noble Citizen, I pitty he should marry againe, Ile walke along, for it is a good old fellow.

SP.SPEAKER: Caro.
SP.P: I warrant, the Wiues of Millan would giue any fellow twenty thousand Duckets, that could but haue the face to beg of the Duke, that all the Citizens in Millan might be bound to the peace of patience, as the Linnen-draper is.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: Oh fy vpon't, 'twould vndoe all vs that are Courti∣ers, we should haue no whoe with the wenches then.

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes.
SP.L: My Lord's come.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: How now, what newes?

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes.
SP.L: None.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Your Lady is with the Duke her Father.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: And we'll to them both presently, whoe's that?

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.P: Friscabaldo, oh! pray call him, and leaue me, wee two haue businesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.L: Ho Signior! Signior Friscabaldo.
The Lord Hipollito.

SP.SPEAKER: Orla.
SP.P: My Noble Lord: my Lord Hipollito! the Dukes Sonne! his braue Daughters braue Husband! how does your honord Lordship! does your Nobility remember so poore a Gentleman as Signior Orlando Friscabaldo! old mad Orlando!

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.P: Oh sir, our friēds! they ought to be vnto vs as our Iew∣els, as dearely valued, being locked vp, & vnseene, as when we weare them in our hands. I see, Friscabaldo, age hath not command of your blood, for all Times sickle has gone ouer you, you are Orlando still.

SP.SPEAKER: Orl,
SP.P:
Why my Lord, are not the fields mowen and cut
downe, and stript bare, and yet weare they not pide coates againe? tho my head be like a Leeke, white: may not my heart be like the blade, greene?

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Scarce can I read the Stories on your brow,
Which age hath writ there, you looke youthfull still.

SP.SPEAKER: Orla.
SP.L: I eate Snakes, my Lord, I eate Snakes.
My heart shall neuer haue a wrinkle in it, so long as I can cry
Hem with a cleare voice.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: You are the happier man, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Orla.
SP.P: Happy man! Ile giue you (my Lord) the true picture of a happy man; I was turning leaues ouer this morning, and found it, an excellent Italian Painter drew it, If I haue it in the right colours, Ile bestow it on your Lordship.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: I stay for it.

SP.SPEAKER: Orla.
SP.L: He that makes gold his wife, but not his whore,
He that at noone-day walkes by a prison doore,
He that 'ith Sunne is neither beame nor moate,
He that's not mad after a Petticoate,
He for whom poore mens curses dig no graue,
He that is neither Lords nor Lawyers slaue,
He that makes This his Sea, and That his Shore,
He that in's Coffin is richer then before,
He that counts Youth his Sword, and Age his Staffe,
He whose right hand carues his owne Epitaph,
He that vpon his death-bead is a Swan,
And Dead, no Crow, he is a happy man.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: It's very well, I thanke you for this Picture.

SP.SPEAKER: Orla.
SP.P: After this Picture (my Lord) doe I striue to haue my face drawne:
SP.L: For I am not couetous,
Am not in debt,
Sit neither at the Dukes side,
Nor lie at his feete.
Wenching and I haue done, no man I wrong,
No man I feare, no man I fee;
I take heed how farre I walke, because I know yonders my home.
I would not die like a rich man, to carry nothing away saue a winding sheete:
But like a good man, to leaue Orlando behind me.
I sowed leaues in my Youth, and I reape now Bookes in my Age.
I fill this hand, and empty this, and when the bell shall toll for me, if I proue a Swan & go singing to my nest, why so?
If a Crow! throw me out for carrion, & pick out mine eyes,
May not old Friscabaldo (my Lord) be merry now! ha?

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: You may, would I were partner in your mirth.

SP.SPEAKER: Orla.
SP.L: I haue a little,
Haue all things;
I haue nothing; I haue no wife, I haue no child, haue no chick, and why should not I be in my Iocundare?

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Is your wife then departed?

SP.SPEAKER: Orla.
SP.L: She's an old dweller in those high Countries,
Yet not from me,
SP.P: Here, she's here: but before me, when a Knaue and a Queane are married, they commonly walke like Serieants together: but a good couple are seldome parted.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: You had a Daughter too sir, had you not?

SP.SPEAKER: Orla.
SP.P: Oh my Lord! this old Tree had one Branch, (and but one Branch growing out of it) It was young, it was faire, it was straight; I prumde it daily, drest it carefully, kept it from the winde, help'd it to the Sunne, yet for all my skill in planting, it grew crooked, it bore Crabs; I hewed it downe,
SP.L: What's become of it, I neither know, nor care.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Then can I tell you whats become of it;
That Branch is witherd.

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.L: So 'twas long agoe.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Her name I thinke was Bellafront, she's dead.

SP.SPEAKER: Orlando.
SP.L: Ha? dead?

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Yes, what of her was left, not worth the keeping,
Euen in my sight was throwne into a Graue.

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.P:
Dead! my last and best peace goe with her, I see deaths a good trencherman, he can eat course homely meat,
as well as the daintiest.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Why, Friscabaldo, was she homely?

SP.SPEAKER: Orla.
SP.P: O my Lord! a Strumpet is one of the Deuils Vines; all the sinnes like so many Poles are stucke vpright out of hell, to be her props, that she may spread vpon them. And when she's ripe, euery Slaue has a pull at her, then must she be prest. The yong beautifull Grape sets the teeth of Lust on edge, yet to taste that lickrish Wine, is to drinke a mans owne damnation. Is she dead?

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Shee's turned to earth.

SP.SPEAKER: Orla.
SP.P: Wod she were turn'd to heauen; Vmh, is she dead! I am glad the world has lost one of his Idols; no Whore∣monger will at midnight beat at the doores; In her graue sleepe all my shame, and her owne; and all my sorrowes, and all her sinnes.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: I'm glad you are wax, not marble; you are made
Of mans best temper, there are now good hopes
That all these heapes of
Ice about your heart,
By which a fathers loue was frozen vp,
Are thawed in these sweet showres fetcht from your eyes,
We are ne'r like Angels till our passion dyes,
She is not dead, but liues vnder worse fate,
I thinke she's poore, and more to clip her wings,
Her Husband at this houre lies in the Iayle,
For killing of a man, to saue his blood,
Ioyne all your force with mine: mine shall be showne,
The getting of his life preserues your owne.

SP.SPEAKER: Orla.
SP.L: In my daughter you will say! does she liue then?
SP.P: I am sorry I wasted teares vpon a Harlot, but the best is I haue a handkercher to drinke them vp, sope can wash them all out agen.
SP.L: Is she poore?

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Trust me, I thinke she is.

SP.SPEAKER: Orla.
SP.P:
Then she's a right Strumper; I ne'r knew any of their trade rich two yeeres together; Siues can hold no
water, nor Harlots hoord vp money; they haue many vents, too many sluces to let it out; Tauernes, Taylors, Bawds, Panders, Fidlers, Swaggerers, Fooles and Knaues, doe all waite vpon a common Harlots trencher: she is the Gally∣pot to which these Drones flye: not for loue to the pot, but for the sweet sucket within it, her money, her money.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.P: I almost dare pawne my word, her bosome giues warmth to no such Snakes; when did you see her?

SP.SPEAKER: Orla.
SP.L: Not seuenteene Summers.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Is your hate so old?

SP.SPEAKER: Orla.
SP.P: Older; it has a white head, and shall neuer dye till she be buried,
SP.L: Her wrongs shall be my bedfellow.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Worke yet his life, since in it liues her fame.

SP.SPEAKER: Orla.
SP.P: No, let him hang, and halfe her infamy departs out of the world: I hate him for her; he taught her first to taste poyson; I hate her for her selfe, because she refused my Physicke.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Nay but Friscabaldo.

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.L: I detest her, I defie both, she's not mine, she's.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Heare her but speake.

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.L: I loue no Marcmaides, Ile not be caught with a quaill pipe.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Y'are now beyond all reason.

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.P: I am then a Beast. Sir, I had rather be a beast, and not dishonor my creation, then be a doting father, & like Time, be the destruction of mine owne broode.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Is't dotage to relieue your child being poore?

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.L: Is't fit for an old man to keepe a whore?

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: 'Tis charity too.

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.L: 'Tis foolery; releeue her!
Were her cold limbes stretcht out vpon a Beere,
I would not sell this durt vnder my nailes
To buy her an houres breath, nor giue this haire,
Vnlesse it were to choke her.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Fare you well, for Ile trouble you no more.

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.P:
And fare you well sir, goe thy waies, we haue few
Lords of thy making, that loue wenches for their honesty; Las my Girle! art thou poore? pouerty dwells next doore to despaire, there's but a wall betweene them; despaire is one of hells Catch-poles; and lest that Deuill arrest her, Ile to her, yet she shall not know me; she shall drinke of my wealth, as beggers doe of running water, freely, yet neuer know from what Fountaines head it flowes. Shall a silly bird picke her owne brest to nourish her yong ones, and can a father see his child starue? That were hard; The Peli∣can does it, and shall not I. Yes, I will victuall the Campe for her, but it shall be by some stratagem; that knaue there her husband will be hanged I feare, Ile keepe his necke out of the nooze if I can, he shall not know how.

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.L: How now knaues, whither wander you?
To seeke your Worship.

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.P: Stay, which of you has my purse, what money haue you about you?

SP.L: Some fifteene or sixteene pounds, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.P: Giue it me, I thinke I haue some gold about me; yes, it's well; leaue my Lodging at Court, and get you home. Come sir, tho I neuer turned any man out of doores, yet Ile be so bold as to pull your Coate ouer your eares.

SP.L: What doe you meane to doe sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.P: Hold thy tongue knaue, take thou my Cloake, I hope I play not the paltry Merchant in this bartring; bid the Steward of my house, sleepe with open eyes in my absence, and to looke to all things, whatsoeuer I command by Letters to be done by you, see it done. So, does it sit well?

SP.L: As if it were made for your Worship.

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.P: You proud Varlets, you need not bee ashamed to weare blue, when your Master is one of your fellowes; away, doe not see me.

SP.SPEAKER: Both.
SP.L: This is excellent.

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.L: I should put on a worse suite too; perhaps I will.
SP.P: My Vizard is on, now to this maske. Say I should shaue off this Honor of an old man, or tye it vp shorter; Well, I will spoyle a good face for once. My beard being off, how should I looke? euen like
SP.L: A Winter Cuckoo, or vnfeatherd Owle;
Yet better lose this haire, then lose her soule.
SP.STAGE: Enter Candido, Lodouico, and Carolo. Lodouico other Guests, and Bride with Prentises.

SP.SPEAKER: Cand.
SP.P: O Gentlemen, so late, y'are very welcome, pray sit downe.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Carolo, did'st ere see such a nest of Caps?

SP.SPEAKER: Asto.
SP.L: Me thinkes
It's a most ciuill and most comely sight.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: What does he 'ith middle looke like?

SP.SPEAKER: Asto.
SP.P: Troth like a spire steeple in a Country Village ouerpeering so many thatcht houses.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: It's rather a long pike staffe against so many buck∣lers without pikes; they sit for all the world like a paire of Organs, and hee's the tall great roaring pipe'ith middest.

SP.SPEAKER: Asto.
SP.L: Ha, ha, ha, ha.

SP.SPEAKER: Cand.
SP.L: What's that you laugh at, Signiors?

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Troth shall I tell you, and aloude Ile tell it,
We laugh to see (yet laugh we not in scorne)
Amongst so many Caps that long Hat worne.

SP.SPEAKER: Lodo.
SP.P: Mine is as tall a felt as any is this day in Millan, and therefore I loue it, for the blocke was cleft out for my head, and fits me to a haire.

SP.SPEAKER: Cand.
SP.L: Indeed you are good obseruers, it shewes strange.
But Gentlemen, I pray neither contemne,
Nor yet deride a ciuill ornament;
I could build so much in the round Caps praise,
That loue this hye roofe, I this flat would raise.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Prethee sweet Bridegrome doo't.

SP.SPEAKER: Cand.
SP.L: So all these guests will pardon me, Ile doo't.

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes.
SP.L: With all our hearts.

SP.SPEAKER: Cand.
SP.L: Thus then in the Caps honor,
To euery Sex and state, both Nature, Time,
The Countries lawes, yea and the very Clime
Doe allot distinct habits, the spruce Courtier
Iets vp and downe in silke: the Warrier
Marches in buffe, the Clowne plods on in gray:
But for these vpper garments thus I say,
The Sea-man has his Cap, par'd without brim,
The Gallants head is featherd, that fits him;
The Soldier has his Murren, women ha Tires;
Beasts haue their head-peeces, and men ha theirs.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Proceed.

SP.SPEAKER: Cand.
SP.L: Each degree has his fashion, it's fit then,
One should be laid by for the Citizen,
And that's the Cap which you see swels not hye,
For Caps are Emblems of humility;
It is a Citizens badge, and first was worne
By'th Romanes; for when any Bondmans turne
Came to be made a Freeman: thus 'twas said,
He to the Cap was call'd; that is, was made
Of Rome a Freeman, but was first close shorne,
And so a Citizens haire is still short worne.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: That close shauing made Barbers a Company,
And now euery Citizen vses it.

SP.SPEAKER: Cand.
SP.L: Of Geometricke figures the most rare,
And perfect'st are the Circle and the square,
The Citty and the Schoole much build vpon
These figures, for both loue proportion.
The City Cap is round, the Schollers square.
To shew that Gouernment and learning are
The perfect'st limbes i'th body of a State:
For without them, all's disproportionate.
If the Cap had no honor, this might reare it,
The Reuerend Fathers of the Law doe weare it.
It's light for Summer, and in cold it sits
Close to the scull, a warme house for the wits;
It shewes the whole face boldly, 'tis not made
As if a man to looke on't were afraide,
Nor like a Drapers shop with broad darke shed,
For hee's no Citizen that hides his head.
Flat Caps as proper are to Citty Gownes,
As to Armors Helmets, or to Kings their Crownes.
Let then the City Cap by none be scornd,
Since with it Princes heads haue beene adornd.
If more the round Caps honor you would know,
How would this long Gowne with this steeple show?

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes.
SP.L: Ha, ha, ha: most vile, most vgly.

SP.SPEAKER: Cand.
SP.L: Pray Signior pardon me, 'twas done in iest.

SP.SPEAKER: Bride.
SP.L: A cup of claret wine there.
Wine: yes forsooth, wine for the Bride.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.L: You ha well set out the Cap, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Nay, that's flat.

SP.SPEAKER: Long.
SP.L: A heaith.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Since his Cap's round, that
SP.STAGE: The Bride hits the Prentice on the lips.
SP.L: Shall goe round. Be bare,
For in the Caps praise all of you haue share.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: The Bride's at cuffes.

SP.SPEAKER: Cand.
SP.P: Oh, peace I pray thee, thus far off I stand, I spied the error of my seruants, she call'd for Claret, and you fill'd out Sacke; that cup giue me, 'tis for an old mans backe, and not for hers. Indeed 'twas but mistaken, aske all these else.

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes.
SP.L: No faith, 'twas but mistaken.
Nay, she tooke it right enough.

SP.SPEAKER: Cand.
SP.L: Good Luke reach her that glasse of Claret.
Here, Mistris Bride, pledge me there.

SP.SPEAKER: Bride.
SP.L: Now Ile none.

SP.SPEAKER: Cand.
SP.L: How now?

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Looke what your Mistris ayles.

SP.P: Nothing, sir, but about filling a wrong glasse, a scuruy tricke.

SP.SPEAKER: Cand.
SP.P: I pray you hold your tongue, my seruant there tells me she is not well.

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes.
SP.L: Step to her, step to her.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: A word with you: doe ye heare? This wench (your new wife) will take you downe in your wedding shooes, vnlesse you hang her vp in her wedding garters.

SP.SPEAKER: Cand.
SP.L: How, hang her in her garters?

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: Will you be a rame Pidgeon still? shall your backe be like a Tortoys shell, to let Carts goe ouer it, yet not to breake? This Shee-cat will haue more liues then your last Pusse had, and will scratch worse, and mouze you worse: looke toot.

SP.SPEAKER: Cand.
SP.L: What would you haue me doe, sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: What would I haue you doe? Sweare, swagger, brawle, fling; for fighting it's no matter, we ha had knocking Pusses enow already; you know, that a woman was made of the rib of a man, and that rib was crooked. The Morall of which is, that a man must from his beginning be crooked to his wife; be you like an Orāge to her, let her cut you neuer so faire, be you sowre as vineger; will you be ruled by me?

SP.SPEAKER: Cand.
SP.L: In any thing that's ciuill, honest, and iust.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Haue you euer a Prentices suite will fit me?

SP.SPEAKER: Cand.
SP.L: I haue the very same which my selfe wore.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: Ile send my man for't within this halfe houre, and within this two houres Ile be your Prentice: the Hen shall not ouercrow the Cocke, Ile sharpen your spurres.

SP.SPEAKER: Cand.
SP.L: It will be but some iest, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Onely a iest: farewell, come Carolo:

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes.
SP.L: Wee'll take our leaues, Sir, too.

SP.SPEAKER: Cand.
SP.P: Pray conceite not ill of my wiues sodaine rising. This young Knight, Sir Lodouico, is deepe seene in Phisicke, and he tells me, the disease call'd the Mother, hangs on my wife, it is a vehement heauing and beating of the Stomacke, and that swelling did with the paine thereof crampe vp her arme, that hit his lips, and brake the glasse: no harme, it was no harme.

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes.
SP.L: No, Signior, none at all.

SP.SPEAKER: Cand.
SP.L: The straightest arrow may flye wide by chance.
But come, we'll cloze this brawle vp in some dance.

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.P: Oh my sweet Husband, wert thou in thy graue, and art aliue agen? O welcome, welcome.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: Doest know me? my cloake prethee lay't vp. Yes faith, my winding sheete was taken out of Lauender, to be stucke with Rosemary, I lackt but the knot here, or here; yet if I had had it, I should ha made a wry mouh at the world like a Playse: but sweetest villaine, I am here now, and I will talke with thee soone.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: And glad am I th'art here.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: Did these heeles caper in shackles? A my little plumpe rogue, Ile beare vp for all this, and flye hye. Catzo Catzo.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Matheo?

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: What sayest, what sayest? Oh braue fresh ayre, a pox on these Grates and gingling of Keyes, and rattling of Iron, Ile beare vp, Ile flye hye wench, hang Tosse.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Matheo, prethee make thy prison thy glasse,
And in it view the wrinkles, and the scarres,
By which thou wert disfigured, viewing them, mend them.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: Ile goe visit all the mad rogues now, and the good roaring boyes.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Thou doest not heare me?

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Yes faith doe I.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.P: Thou hast beene in the hands of misery, and tane strong Physicke, prethee now be sound.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: Yes. S'foot, I wonder how the inside of a Tauerne lookes now. Oh when shall I bizle, bizle?

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.P: Nay see, th'art thirsty still for poyson, come, I will not haue thee swagger.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Honest Apes face.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: 'Tis that sharpned an axe to cut thy throate.
Good Loue, I would not haue thee sell thy substance
And time (worth all) in those damned shops of Hell;
Those Dycing houses, that stand neuer well,
But when they stand most ill, that foure-squared sinne
Has almost lodg'd vs in the beggers Inne.
Besides (to speake which euen my soule does grieue)
A sort of Rauens haue hung vpon thy sleeue,
And fed vpon thee: good Mat. (if you please) so base as
Scorne to spread wing amongst these;
By them thy fame is speckled, yet it showes
Cleare amongst them; so Crowes are faire with Crowes.
Custome in sinne, giues sinne a louely dye.
Blacknesse in Mores is no deformity.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: Bellafront, Bellafront, I protest to thee, I sweare, as I hope my soule, I will turne ouer a new leafe, the prison I confesse has bit me, the best man that sayles in such a Ship, may be lowsy.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: One knockes at doore.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: Ile be the Porter: they shall see, a Iayle cannot hold a braue spirit, Ile flye hye.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: How wilde is his behauiour! oh, I feare
He's spoyld by prison, he's halfe damned comes there,
But I must sit all stormes: when a full sayle his
Fortunes spred, he loued me: being now poore,
Ile beg for him, and no wife can doe more.
SP.STAGE: Enter Matheo, and Orlando like a Seruingman.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Come in pray, would you speake with me, sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.L: Is your name Signior Matheo?

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: My name is Signior Matheo.

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.L: Is this Gentlewoman your wife, sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: This Gentlewoman is my wife, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.P: The Destinies spin a strong and euen thread of both your loues: the Mothers owne face, I ha not forgot that, I'm an old man, sir, & am troubled with awhoreson salt rhew me, that I cannot hold my water. Gentlewoman, the last man I serued was your Father.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: My Father? any tongue that sounds his name,
Speakes Musicke to me: welcome good old man.
How does my father? liues he? has he health?
How does my father? I so much doe shame him,
So much doe wound him, that I scarce dare name him.

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.L: I can speake no more.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: How now old Lad, what doest cry?

SP.SPEAKER: Orl
SP.P: The rhewme still, sir, nothing else; I should be well seasond, for mine eyes lye in brine: looke you, sir, I haue a suite to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Math.
SP.L: What is't my little white pate?

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.L: Troth, sir, I haue a mind to serue your Worship.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: To serue me? Troth, my friend, my fortunes are, as a man may say—

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.P: Nay looke you, sir, I know when all sinnes are old in vs, and goe vpon Crutches, that Couetousnesse does but then lie in her Cradle; 'Tis not so with me. Letchery loues to dwell in the fairest lodging, and Couetousnesse in the oldest buildings, that are ready to fall: but my white head, sir, is no Inne for such a gossip. If a Seruingman at my yeeres be not stored with bisket enough, that has sayled about the world to serue him the voyage out of his life, and to bring him East-home; Ill pitty but all his daies should be fasting daies: I care not so much for wages, for I haue scraped a handfull of gold together; I haue a little money, sir, which I would put into your Worships hands, not so much to make it more.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: No, no, you say well, thou sayest well; but I must tell you: How much is the money, sayest thou?

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.L: About twenty pound, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: Twenty pound? Let me see: that shall bring thee in, after ten per centum, per annum.

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.P: No, no, no, sir, no; I cannot abide to haue money in∣gender: fye vpon this siluer Lechery, fye; if I may haue meat to my mouth, and rags to my backe, and a flock-bed to snort vpon, when I die, the longer liuer take all.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: A good old Boy, yfaith, if thou seruest me, thou shalt eat as I eat, drinke as I drinke, lye as I lye, and ride as I ride.

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.L: That's if you haue money to hire horses.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat. and Front.
SP.P:
What doest thou thinke on't? This good old
Lad here shall sere me.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Alas, Matheo, wilt thou load a backe
That is already broke?

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: Peace, pox on you, peace, there's a tricke in't, I flye hye, it shall be so, Front. as I tell you: giue me thy hand, thou shalt serue me yfaith: welcome: as for your money—

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.L: Nay, looke you sir, I haue it here.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: Pesh, keepe it thy selfe, man, and then th'art sure 'tis safe.

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.P: Safe! and 'twere ten thousand Duckets, your Worship should be my cash-keeper; I haue heard what your Wor∣ship is, an excellent dunghill Cocke, to scatter all abroad: but Ile venture twenty pounds on's head.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: And did'st thou serue my Worshipfull Father-in-law, Signior Orlando Friscabaldo, that mad man once?

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.L: I serued him so long, till he turned me out of doores.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: It's a notable Chuffe, I ha not seene him many a day.

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.P: No matter and you ne'r see him: it's an arrant Gran∣dy, a Churle, and as damnd a cut-throat.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Thou villaine, curb thy tongue, thou art a Iudas,
To sell thy Masters name to slander thus.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Away Asse, he speakes but truth, thy father is a—

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Gentleman.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: And an old knaue, there's more deceit in him then in sixteene Poticaries: it's a Deuill, thou maist beg, starue, hang, damne; does he send thee so much as a cheese?

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.L: Or so much as a Gammon of Bacon,
Hee'll giue it his Dogs first.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: A Iayle, a Iayle.

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.L: A Iew, a Iew, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: A Dog.

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.L: An English Mastiffe, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Pox rot out his old stinking garbage.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Art not ashamed to strike an absent man thus?
Art not ashamed to let this vild Dog barke,
And bite my Father thus? Ile not indure it;
Out of my doores, base slaue.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: Your dores! a vengeance? I shall liue to cut that old rogues throat, for all you take his part thus.

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.L: He shall liue to see thee hangd first.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: Gods so my Lord, your Lordship is most welcome, I'm proud of this, my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Was bold to see you.
Is that your wife?

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Yes sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Ile borrow her lip.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: With all my heart, my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.L: Who's this, I pray sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: My Lord Hipollito: what's thy name?

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.L: Pacheco.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: Pacheco, fine name; Thou seest, Pacheco, I keepe company with no Scondrels, nor base fellowes.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Came not my Footman to you?

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Yes my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: I sent by him a Diamond and a Letter,
Did you receiue them?

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Yes my Lord, I did.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Read you the letter?

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: O're and o're 'tis read.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: And faith your answer?

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Now the time's not fit,
You see, my Husbands here.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Ile now then leaue you,
And choose mine houre; but ere I part away,
Harke, you remember I must haue no nay.
Matheo, I will leaue you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: A glasse of wine.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Not now, Ile visit you at other times.
Y'are come off well then?

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: Excellent well, I thanke your Lordship: I owe you my life, my Lord; and will pay my best blood in any seruice of yours.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.P: Ile take no such deare payment, harke you Matheo, I know, the prison is a gulfe, if money runne low with you, my purse is yours: call for it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: Faith my Lord, I thanke my starres, they send me downe some; I cannot sinke, so long as these bladders hold.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: I will not see your fortunes ebbe, pray try.
To starue in full barnes were fond modesty.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Open the doore, sirra.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.P: Drinke this, and anon I pray thee giue thy Mistris this.

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.L: O Noble Spirit, if no worse guests here dwell,
My blue coate sits on my old shoulders well.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: The onely royall fellow, he's bounteous as the Indies,
what's that he said to thee, Bellafront?

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: I prethee good Girle?

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Why I tell you nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: Nothing? it's well: trickes, that I must be behol∣den to a scald hot-liuerd gotish Gallant, to stand with my cap in my hand, and vaile bonnet, when I ha spred as lofty sayles as himselfe, wud I had beene hanged. Nothing▪ Pa∣checo, brush my cloake.

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.L: Where is't, sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Come, wee'll flye hye.
Nothing? there is a whore still in thine eye.

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.L: My twenty pounds flyes high, O wretched woman,
This varlot's able to make Lucrece common.
SP.P: How now Mistris? has my Master dyed you into this sad colour?

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.P: Fellow, be gone I pray thee; if thy tongue itch after talke so much, seeke out thy Master, th'art a fit instrument for him.

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.L: Zownes, I hope he will not play vpon me?

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Play on thee? no, you two will flye together,
Because you are rouing arrowes of one feather.
Would thou wouldst leaue my house, thou ne'r shalt
Please, me weaue thy nets ne'r so hye,
Thou shalt be but a spider in mine eye.
Th'art ranke with poyson, poyson temperd well,
Is food for health; but thy blacke tongue doth swell
With venome, to hurt him that gaue thee bread,
To wrong men absent, is to spurne the dead.
And so did'st thou thy Master, and my Father.

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.P: You haue small reason to take his part; for I haue heard him say fiue hundred times, you were as arrant a whore as euer stiffned tiffany neckcloathes in water-starch vpon a Saturday 'ith afternoone.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Let him say worse, when for the earths offence
Hot vengeance through the marble cloudes is driuen,
Is't fit earth shoot agen those darts at heauen?

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.P: And so if your Father call you whore, you'll not call him old knaue: Friscabaldo, she carries thy mind vp and downe; she's thine owne flesh, blood, and bone; troth Mi∣stris, to tell you true, the fireworkes that ran from me vpon lines against my good old Master, your father, were but to try how my young Master, your Husband loued such squibs: but it's well knowne, I loue your father as my selfe; Ile ride for him at mid-night, runne for you by Owle-light; Ile dye for him, drudge for you; Ile flye low, and Ile flye hye (as my Master saies) to doe you good, if you'll forgiue me.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: I am not made of marble: I forgiue thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.P: Nay, if you were made of marble, a good Stone∣cutter might cut you: I hope the twenty pound I deliuered to my Master, is in a sure hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: In a sure hand I warrant thee for spending.

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.P: I see my yong Master is a madcap, and a bonus socius, I loue him well, Mistris: yet as well as I loue him, Ile not play the knaue with you; looke you, I could cheat you of this purse full of money; but I am an old Lad, and I scorne to cunny-catch: yet I ha beene Dog at a Cony in my time.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: A purse, where hadst it?

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.P: The Gentleman that went away, whisperd in mine care, and charged me to giue it you.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: The Lord Hipollito?

SP.SPEAKER: Orla.
SP.L: Yes, if he be a Lord, he gaue it me.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: 'Tis all gold.

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.P: 'Tis like so: it may be, he thinkes you want money, and therefore bestowes his almes brauely, like a Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: He thinkes a siluer net can catch the poore,
Here's baite to choake a Nun, and turne her whore.
Wilt thou be honest to me?

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.P: As your nailes to your fingers, which I thinke ne∣uer deceiued you.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Thou to this Lord shalt goe, commend me to him,
And tell him this, the Towne has held out long,
Because (within) 'twas rather true, then strong.
To sell it now were base; Say 'tis no hold
Built of weake stuffe, to be blowne vp with gold.
He shall beleeue thee by this token, or this; if not, by this.

SP.SPEAKER: Orla.
SP.L: Is this all?

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: This is all.

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.L: Mine owne Girle still.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: A Starre may shoote, not fall.

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.P: A Starre? nay, thou art more then the moone, for thou hast neither changing quarters, nor a man standing in thy circle with a bush of thornes. Is't possible the Lord Hipollito, whose face is as ciuill as the outside of a Dedicato∣ry Booke, should be a Muttonmunger? A poore man has but one Ewe, and this Grandy Sheepe-biter leaues whole Flockes of fat Weathers (whom he may knocke downe) to deuoure this. Ile trust neither Lord nor Butcher with quicke flesh for this tricke; the Cuckoo I see now sings all the yeere, though euery man cannot heare him, but Ile spoyle his notes; can neither Loue-letters, nor the Deuils common Pick-lockes (Gold) nor Precious Stones make my Girle draw vp her Percullis: hold out still, wench.
SP.L: All are not Bawds (I see now) that keepe doores,
Nor all good wenches that are markt for Whores.
SP.STAGE: Enter Candido, Lodouico like a Prentice.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P:
Come, come, come, what doe yee lacke, sir? what
doe ye lacke, sir? what is't ye lacke, sir? is not my Worship well suited? did you euer see a Gentleman better disguised?

SP.SPEAKER: Cand.
SP.L: Neuer, beleeue me, Signior.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: Yes: but when he has bin drunke, there be Prenti∣ces would make mad Gallants, for they would spend all, and drinke, and whore, and so forth; and I see we Gallants could make mad Prentices. How does thy wife like me? Nay, I must not be so sawcy, then I spoyle all: pray you how does my Mistris like me?

SP.SPEAKER: Cand.
SP.L: Well: for she takes you for a very simple fellow.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: And they that are taken for such, are commonly the arrantest knaues: but to our Comedy, come.

SP.SPEAKER: Cand.
SP.L: I shall not act it, chide you say, and fret,
And grow impatient: I shall neuer doo't.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: S'blood, cannot you doe as all the world does? counterfet.

SP.SPEAKER: Cand.
SP.P: Were I a Painter, that should liue by drawing no∣thing but Pictures of an angry man, I should not earne my colours; I cannot doo't.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: Remember y'are a Linnen Draper, and that if you giue your wife a yard, she'll take an ell: giue her not there∣fore a quarter of your yard, not a nayle.

SP.SPEAKER: Cand.
SP.P: Say I should turne to Ice, and nip her loue now 'tis but in the blood.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Well, say she's nipt.

SP.SPEAKER: Cand.
SP.L: It will so ouerchange her heart with griefe,
That like a Cannon, when her sighes goe off,
She in her duty either will recoyle,
Or breake in pieces and so dye: her death,
By my vnkindnesse might be counted murther.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: Dye? neuer, neuer; I doe not bid you beat her, nor giue her blacke eyes, nor pinch her sides: but crosse her humours. Are not Bakers armes the skales of Iustice? yet is not their bread light? and may not you I pray bridle her with a sharpe bit, yet ride her gently?

SP.SPEAKER: Cand.
SP.P:
Well, I will try your pills, doe you your faithfull seruice, and bee ready still at a pinch to helpe me in this
part, or else I shall be out cleane.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Come, come, Ile prompt you.

SP.SPEAKER: Cand.
SP.L: Ile call her forth now, shall I?

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Doe, doe, brauely.

SP.SPEAKER: Cand.
SP.L: Luke, I pray bid your Mistris to come hither.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Luke, I pray bid your Mistris to come hither.

SP.SPEAKER: Cand.
SP.L: Sirra, bid my wife come to me: why, when?

SP.SPEAKER: Luke.
SP.L: Presently, sir, she comes.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: La you, there's the eccho, she comes.

SP.SPEAKER: Bride.
SP.L: What is your pleasure with me?

SP.SPEAKER: Cand.
SP.L: Mary wife,
I haue intent, and (you see) this stripling here,
He beares good will and liking to my trade,
And meanes to deale in Linnen.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: Yes indeed, sir, I would deale in Linnen, if my Mi∣stris like me so well as I like her?

SP.SPEAKER: Cand.
SP.P: I hope to finde him honest, pray good wife looke that his bed and chamber be made ready.

SP.SPEAKER: Bride.
SP.P: Y'are best to let him hire mee for his maide? I looke to his bed? looke too't your selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Cand.
SP.L: Euen so
I sweare to you a great oath.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Sweare, cry Zoundes.

SP.SPEAKER: Cand.
SP.L: I will not, goe to wife, I will not,

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: That your great oath?

SP.SPEAKER: Cand.
SP.L: Swallow these gudgeons.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Well said.

SP.SPEAKER: Cand.
SP.L: Then fast, then you may choose.
You know at Table
What trickes you played, swaggerd, broke glasses! Fie,
Fie, fie, fie: and now before my Prentice here
You make an asse of me; thou, (what shall I call thee?)

SP.SPEAKER: Bride.
SP.L: Euen what you will.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Call her arrant whore.

SP.SPEAKER: Cand.
SP.P: Oh fie, by no meanes, then she'll call me Cuckold, sirrah, goe looke to'th shop: how does this show?

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P:
Excellent well, Ile goe looke to the shop, sir. Fine
Cambricks, Lawnes, what doe you lacke.

SP.SPEAKER: Cand.
SP.L: A curst Cowes milke I ha drunke once before,
And 'twas so ranke in taste, Ile drinke no more.
Wife, Ile tame you.

SP.SPEAKER: Bride.
SP.L: You may, sir, if you can,
But at a wrastling I haue seene a fellow
Limbd like an Oxe, throwne by a little man.

SP.SPEAKER: Cand.
SP.L: And so you'll throw me. Reach me (Knaues) a yard.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: A Yard for my Master.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Prent.
SP.L: My Master is growne valiant.

SP.SPEAKER: Cand.
SP.L: Ile teach you fencing trickes.

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes.
SP.L: Rare, rare; a prize.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: What will you doe, sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Can.
SP.L: Mary, my good Prentice, nothing but breathe my wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Bride.
SP.L: Breathe me with your yard?

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: No, he'll but measure you out, forsooth.

SP.SPEAKER: Bride.
SP.L: Since you'll needes fence, handle your weapon well,
For if you take a yard, Ile take an ell.
Reach me an ell.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: An ell for my Mistris.
SP.P: Keep the lawes of the Noble Science, sir, & measure weapons with her; your yard is a plaine Heathenish weapon; 'tis too short, she may giue you a handfull, & yet you'l not reach her.

SP.SPEAKER: Cand.
SP.L: Yet I ha the longer arme, come fall too't roundly,
And spare not me (wife) for Ile lay't on soundly.
If o're husbands their wiues will needes be Masters,
We men will haue a law to win't at wasters

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: 'Tis for the breeches, is't not?

SP.SPEAKER: Cand.
SP.L: For the breeches.

SP.SPEAKER: Bride.
SP.L: Husband I am for you, Ile not strike in iest.

SP.SPEAKER: Cand.
SP.L: Nor I.

SP.SPEAKER: Bride.
SP.L: But will you signe to one request?

SP.SPEAKER: Cand.
SP.L: What's that?

SP.SPEAKER: Bride.
SP.L: Let me giue the first blow.

SP.SPEAKER: Cand.
SP.L: The first blow, wife, shall I? Prompt?

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Let her ha'te.
If she strike hard, in to her, and breake her pate.

SP.SPEAKER: Cand.
SP.L: A bargaine. Strike.

SP.SPEAKER: Bride.
SP.L: Then guard you from this blow,
For I play all at legges, but 'tis thus low.
Behold, I am such a cunning Fencer growne,
I keepe my ground, yet downe I will be throwne
With the least blow you giue me, I disdaine
The wife that is her husbands Soueraigne.
She that vpon your pillow first did rest,
They say, the breeches wore, which I detest.
The taxe which she imposed vpon you, I abate you,
If me you make your Master, I shall hate you.
The world shall iudge who offers fairest play;
You win the breeches, but I win the day.

SP.SPEAKER: Cand.
SP.L: Thou winst the day indeed, giue me thy hand,
Ile challenge thee no more: my patient brest
Plaid thus the Rebell, onely for a iest:
Here's the rancke rider that breakes Colts, 'tis he
Can tame the mad folkes, and curst wiues.

SP.SPEAKER: Bride.
SP.L: Who, your man?

SP.SPEAKER: Cand.
SP.L: My man? my Master, tho his head be bare,
But he's so courteous, he'll put off his haire.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: Nay, if your seruice be so hot, a man cannot keepe his haire on, Ile serue you no longer.

SP.SPEAKER: Bride.
SP.L: Is this your Schoolemaster?

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: Yes faith, wench, I taught him to take thee downe: I hope thou canst take him downe without teaching; you ha got the conquest, and you both are friends.

SP.SPEAKER: Cand.
SP.L: Beare witnes else.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: My Prentiship then ends.

SP.SPEAKER: Cand.
SP.L: For the good seruice you to me haue done,
I giue you all your yeeres.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: I thanke you Master.
Ile kisse my Mistris now, that she may say,
My man was bound, and free all in one day.

SP.SPEAKER: Infae.
SP.L: From whom saiest thou?

SP.SPEAKER: Orla.
SP.L: From a poore Gentlewoman, Madam, whom I serue.

SP.SPEAKER: Infae.
SP.L: And whats your businesse?

SP.SPEAKER: Orla.
SP.P: This, Madam: my poore Mistris has a waste piece of ground, which is her owne by inheritance, and left to her by her mother; There's a Lord now that goes about, not to take it cleane from her, but to inclose it to himselfe, and to ioyne it to a piece of his Lordships.

SP.SPEAKER: Infae.
SP.L: What would she haue me doe in this?

SP.SPEAKER: Orla.
SP.P: No more, Madam, but what one woman should doe for another in such a case. My Honourable Lord, your Husband would doe any thing in her behalfe, but shee had rather put her selfe into your hands, because you (a woman) may doe more with the Duke your Father.

SP.SPEAKER: Infae.
SP.L: Where lyes this Land?

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.P: Within a stones cast of this place; my Mistris, I think, would be content to let him enioy it after her decease, if that would serue his turne, so my Master would yeeld too: but she cannot abide to heare that the Lord should meddle with it in her life time.

SP.SPEAKER: Infae.
SP.P: Is she then married? why stirres not her Husband in it?

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.P: Her Husband stirres in it vnder hand: but because the other is a great rich man, my Master is loth to be seene in it too much.

SP.SPEAKER: Infae.
SP.L: Let her in writing draw the cause at large:
And I will moue the Duke.

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.P: 'Tis set downe, Madam, here in blacke and white already: worke it so, Madam, that she may keepe her owne without disturbance, grieuance, molestation, or medling of any other; and she bestowes this purse of gold on your La∣dyship.

SP.SPEAKER: Infae.
SP.L: Old man, Ile pleade for her, but take no fees:
Giue Lawyers them, I swim not in that flood,
Ile touch no gold, till I haue done her good.

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.P:
I would all Proctors Clearkes were of your minde, I should law more amongst them then I doe then; here, Ma∣dam, is the suruey, not onely of the Mannor it selfe, but of
the Grange house, with euery Medow pasture, Plough-land, Cony-borough, Fish-pond, hedge, ditch, and bush that stands in it.

SP.SPEAKER: Infae.
SP.P: My Husbands name, and hand and seale at armes to a Loue-letter? Where hadst thou this writing?

SP.SPEAKER: Orla.
SP.P: From the foresaid party, Madam, that would keepe the foresaid Land out of the foresaid Lords fingers.

SP.SPEAKER: Infae.
SP.L: My Lord turnd Ranger now?

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.P: Y'are a good Huntresse, Lady, you ha found your Game already; your Lord would faine be a Ranger, but my Mistris requests you to let him runne a course in your owne Parke, if you'll not doo't for loue, then doo't for money; she has no white money, but there's gold, or else she praies you to ring him by this token, and so you shall be sure his nose will not be rooting other mens pastures.

SP.SPEAKER: Infae.
SP.L: This very purse was wouen with mine owne hands,
This Diamond on that very night, when he
Vntyed my Virgin girdle, gaue I him:
And must a common Harlot share in mine?
Od man, to quit thy paines, take thou the gold.

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.L: Not I, Madam, old Seruingmen want no money.

SP.SPEAKER: Infae.
SP.L: Cupid himselfe was sure his Secretary,
These nes are euen the Arrowes Loue let flies,
The very Incke dropt out of Uenus eyes.

SP.SPEAKER: Orla.
SP.P: I doe not thinke, Madam, but hee fetcht off some Poet or other for those lines, for they are parlous Hawkes to flie at wenches.

SP.SPEAKER: Infae
SP.L: Here's honied poyson, to me he ne'r thus writ,
But Lust can set a double edge on wit.

SP.SPEAKER: Orla.
SP.P: Nay, that's true, Madam, a wench will whet any thing, if it be not too dull.

SP.SPEAKER: Infae.
SP.L: Oathes, promises, preferments, Iewels, gold,
What snares should breake, if all these cannot hold?
What creature is thy Mistris?

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.P: One of those creatures that are contrary to man; a woman.

SP.SPEAKER: Infae.
SP.L: What manner of woman?

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.P: A little tiny woman, lower then your Ladiship by head and shoulders, but as mad a wench as euer vnlaced a petticote: these things should I indeed haue deliuered to my Lord your Husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Infae.
SP.P: They are deliuered better: Why should she send backe these things?

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.L: Ware, ware, there's knauery.

SP.SPEAKER: Infae.
SP.L: Strumpets like cheating gamesters will not win
At first: these are but baites to draw him in.
How might I learne his hunting houres?

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.P: The Irish Footman can tell you all his hunting houres, the Parke he hunts in, the Doe he would strike, that Irish Shackatory beates the bush for him, and knowes all; he brought that Letter, and that Ring; he is the Carrier.

SP.SPEAKER: Infae.
SP.P: Knowest thou what other gifts haue past betweene them?

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.L: Little S. Patricke knowes all.

SP.SPEAKER: Infae.
SP.L: Him Ise examine presently.

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.L: Not whilest I am here, sweet Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Infae.
SP.L: Be gon then, & what lyes in me command.

SP.SPEAKER: Infae.
SP.P: Come hither sirra, how much cost those Satins, and cloth of Siluer, which my husband sent by you to a low Gentlewoman yonder?

SP.SPEAKER: Bry.
SP.P: Faat Sattins? faat Siluers, faat low Gentlefolkes? dow pratest dow knowest not what, yfaat la.

SP.SPEAKER: Infae.
SP.L: She there, to whom you carried letters.

SP.SPEAKER: Bry.
SP.P: By dis hand and bod dow saist true, if I did so, oh how? I know not a letter a de Booke yfaat la.

SP.SPEAKER: Infae.
SP.P: Did your Lord neuer send you with a Ring, sir, set with a Diamond?

SP.SPEAKER: Bry.
SP.P: Neuer, sa crees sa me, neuer; he may runne at a tow∣sand rings yfaat, and I neuer hold his stirrop, till he leape in∣to de saddle. By S. Patricke, Madam, I neuer touch my Lords Diamond, nor euer had to doe, yfaat la, with any of his pre∣cious stones.

SP.SPEAKER: Infae.
SP.L: Are you so close, you Bawd, you pandring slaue?

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: How now? why Infaelice? what's your quarrell?

SP.SPEAKER: Infae.
SP.L: Out of my sight, base varlet, get thee gone.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Away you rogue.

SP.SPEAKER: Bry.
SP.P: Slawne loot, fare de well, fare de well. Ah marragh frofat boddah breen.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: What, growne a fighter? prethee what's the matter?

SP.SPEAKER: Infae.
SP.P: If you'll needs know, it was about the clocke: how workes the day, my Lord, (pray) by your watch?

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.P: Lest you cuffe me, Ile tell you presently: I am neere two.

SP.SPEAKER: Infae.
SP.L: How, two? I am scarce at one.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: One of vs then goes false.

SP.SPEAKER: Infae.
SP.L: Then sure 'tis you,
Mine goes by heauens Diall, (the Sunne) and it goes true.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: I thinke (indeed) mine runnes somewhat too fast.

SP.SPEAKER: Infae.
SP.L: Set it to mine (at one) then.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: One? 'tis past:
'Tis past one by the Sunne.

SP.SPEAKER: Infae.
SP.L: Faith then belike,
Neither your clocke nor mine does truely strike,
And since it is vncertaine which goes true,
Better be false at one, then false at two.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Y'are very pleasant, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Infae.
SP.L: Yet not merry.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Why Infaelice, what should make you sad?

SP.SPEAKER: Infae.
SP.L: Nothing my Lord, but my false watch, pray tell me,
You see, my clocke, or yours is out of frame,
Must we vpon the Workeman lay the blame,
Or on your selues that keepe them?

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Faith on both.
He may by knauery spoile them, we by sloth,
But why talke you all riddle thus? I read
Strange Comments in those margines of your lookes:
Your cheekes of late are (like bad printed Bookes)
So dimly charactred, I scarce can spell,
One line of loue in them. Sure all's not well.

SP.SPEAKER: Infae.
SP.L: All is not well indeed, my dearest Lord,
Locke vp thy gates of hearing, that no sound
Of what I speake ma enter.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: What meanes this?

SP.SPEAKER: Infae.
SP.L: Or if my owne tongue must my selfe betray,
Count it a dreame, or turne thine eyes away,
And thinke me not thy wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Why doe you kneele?

SP.SPEAKER: Infae.
SP.P: Earth is sinnes cushion: when the sicke soule feeles her selfe growing poore, then she turnes begger, cryes and kneeles for helpe; Hipollito (for husband I dare not call thee) I haue slolne that Iewell of my chaste honour (which was onely thine) and giuen it to a slaue.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Hah?

SP.SPEAKER: Infae.
SP.L: On thy pillow adultery & lust haue slpt, thy Groome
Hath climbed the vnlawfull tree, and pluckt the sweets,
A villaine hath vsurped a husbands sheetes.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: S'death, who, (a Cuckold) who?

SP.SPEAKER: Infae.
SP.L: This Irish Footman.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.P: Worse then damnation, a wild Kerne, a Frogge, a Dog: whom Ile scarce spurne. Longed you for Shamocke? were it my fathers father (heart) Ile kill him, although I take him on his death-bed gasping 'twixt heauen and hell; a shag-haired Cur? Bold Strumpet, why hangest thou on me? thinkst Ile be a Bawde to a Whore, because she's Noble?

SP.SPEAKER: Infae.
SP.L: I beg but this,
Set not my shame out to the worlds broad eye,
Yet let thy vengeance (like my fault) soare hye,
So it be in darkned clowdes.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Darkned! my hornes
Cannot be darkned, nor shall my reuenge.
A Harlot to my slaue? the act is base,
Common, but foule, so shall thy disgrace:
Could not I feed your appetite? oh women
You were created Angels, pure and faire;
But since the first fell, tempting Deuils you are,
You should be mens blisse, but you proue their rods.
Were there no women, men might liue like gods:
You ha beene too much downe already, rise,
Get from my sight, and henceforth shun my bed,
Ile with no Strumpets breath be poysoned.
As for your Irish Lubrican, that spirit
Whom by prepostrous charmes thy lust hath raised
In a wrong Circle, him Ile damne more blacke
Then any Tyrants soule.

SP.SPEAKER: Infae.
SP.L: Hipollito?

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.P: Tell me, didst thou baite Hawkes to draw him to thee, or did he bewitch thee?

SP.SPEAKER: Infae.
SP.L: The slaue did woo me.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.P: Two wooes in that Skreech-owles language? Oh who would trust your corcke-heeld sex? I thinke to sate your lust, you would loue a Horse, a Beare, a croaking Toade, so your hot itching veines might haue their bound, then the wild Irish Dart was throwne. Come, how? the manner of this fight.

SP.SPEAKER: Infae.
SP.L: 'Twas thus, he gaue me this battery first. Oh I
Mistake, beleeue me, all this in beaten gold:
Yet I held out, but at length this was charm'd.
What? change your Diamond wench, the act is base,
Common, but foule, so shall not your disgrace:
Could not I feed your appetite? Oh Men,
You were created Augels, pure and faire,
But since the first fell, worse then Deuils you are.
You should our shields be, but you proue our rods.
Were there no Men, Women might liue like gods.
Guilty my Lord?

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Yes, guilty my good Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Infae.
SP.L: Nay, you may laugh, but henceforth shun my bed,
With no whores leauings Ile be poysoned.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: O're-reach'd so finely? 'Tis the very Diamond
And Letter which I sent: this villany
Some Spider closely weaues, whose poysond bulke
I must let forth. Who's there without?

SP.SPEAKER: Seruant.
SP.L: My Lord calls.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Send me the Footman.

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.L: Call the Footman to my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: It can be no man else, that Irish Iudas,
Bred in a Country where no venom prospers,
But in the Nations blood hath thus betraid me.
Slaue, get you from your seruice.

SP.SPEAKER: Bry.
SP.L: Faat meanest thou by this now?

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Question me not, nor tempt my fury, villaine,
Couldst thou turne all the Mountaines in the land,
To hills of gold, and to giue me; here thou stayest not.

SP.SPEAKER: Bry.
SP.L: I faat, I care not.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Prate not, but get thee gone, I shall send else.

SP.SPEAKER: Bry.
SP.P: I, doe predy, I had rather haue thee make a scabbard of my guts, and let out all de Irish puddings in my poore belly, den to be a false knaue to de I faat, I will neuer see dyne own sweet face more. A mawhid deer a gra, fare de well, fare de well, I wil goe steale Cowes agen in Ireland.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.P: He's damn'd that rais'd this whirlewind, which hath blowne
SP.L: Into her eyes this iealousie: yet Ile on,
Ile on, stood armed Deuils staring in my face,
To be pursued in flight, quickens the race,
Shall my blood streames by a wiues lust be bard?
Fond woman, no: Iron growes by strokes more hard,
Lawlesse desires are seas scorning all bounds,
Or sulphure which being ram'd vp, more confounds,
Strugling with mad men, madnes nothing tames,
Winds wrastling with great fires, incense the flames.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: How now, what ayles your Master?

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.P: Has taken a yonger brothers purge, forsooth, and that workes with him.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Where is his Cloake and Rapier?

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.P: He has giuen vp his Cloake, and his Rapier is bound to the Peace: If you looke a little higher, you may see that another hath entred into hatband for him too. Sixe and foure haue put him into this sweat.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Where's all his money?

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.P: 'Tis put ouer by exchange: his doublet was going to be translated, but for me: if any man would ha lent but halfe a ducket on his beard, the haire of it had stuft a paire of breeches by this time; I had but one poore penny, and that I was glad to niggle out, and buy a holly-wand to grace him thorow the streete. As hap was, his bootes were on, and then I dustied, to make people thinke he had beene riding, and I had runne by him.

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.L: Oh me, how does my sweet Matheo?

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: Oh Rogue, of what deuilish stuffe are these Dice made off? of the parings of the Deuils cornes of his toes, that they runne thus damnably.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: I prethee vex not.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: If any handy-crafts man was euer suffred to keep shop in hell, it will be a Dice-maker; he's able to vndoe more soules then the Deuill; I plaid with mine owne Dice, yet lost. Ha you any money?

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Las I ha none.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: Must haue money, must haue some, must haue a Cloake, and Rapier, and things: will you goe set your lime∣twigs, and get me some birds, some money?

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: What limetwigs should I set?

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: You will not then? Must haue cash and pictures: doe ye heare, (frailty) shall I walke in a Plimouth Cloake, (that's to say) like a rogue, in my hose and doublet, and a crabtree cudgell in my hand, and you swimme in your Sat∣tins? must haue money, come.

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.L: Is't bed-time, Master, that you vndo my Mistris?

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Vndoe me? Yes, yes, at these riflings
I haue beene too often.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Helpe to flea, Pacheco.

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.L: Fleaing call you it?

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Ile pawne you by'th Lord, to your very eye-browes.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: With all my heart, since heauen will haue me poore,
As good he drown'd at sea, as drown'd at shore.

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.L: Why heare you, sir? yfaith doe not make away her Gowne.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: Oh it's Summer, it's Summer; your onely fashion for a woman now, is to be light, to be light.

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.P: Why, pray sir, employ some of that money you haue of mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: Thine? Ile starue first, Ile beg first; when I touch a penny of that, let these fingers ends rot.

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.P: So they may, for that's past touching. I saw my twenty pounds flye hie.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: Knowest thou neuer a damn'd Broker about the Citty?

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.L: Damn'd Broker? yes, fiue hundred.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: The Gowne stood me in aboue twenty Duckets, borrow ten of it, cannot liue without siluer.

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.L: Ile make what I can of it, sir, Ile be your Broker,
But not your damb'd broker: Oh thou scuruy knaue,
What makes a wife turne whore, but such a slaue?

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: How now little chicke, what aylest, weeping
SP.P: For a handfull of Taylors shreds? pox on them, are there not silkes enow at Mercers?

SP.SPEAKER: Bel
SP.L: I care not for gay feathers, I.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: What doest care for then? why doest grieue?

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Why doe I grieue? A thousand sorrowes strike
At one poore heart, and yet it liues. Matheo,
Thou art a Gamester, prethee throw at all,
Set all vpon one cast, we kneele and pray,
And struggle for life, yet must be cast away.
Meet misery quickly then, split all, sell all,
And when thou hast sold all, spend it, but I beseech thee
Build not thy mind on me to coyne thee more,
To get it wouldst thou haue me play the whore?

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: 'Twas your profession before I married you.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Vmh? it was indeed: if all men should be branded
For sinnes long since laid vp, who could be saued?
The Quarter day's at hand, how will you doe
To pay the Rent, Matheo?

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: Why? doe as all of our occupation doe against Quarter daies; breake vp house, remoue, shift your lodg∣ings, pox a your Quarters.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Where's this Gallant?

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: Signior Lodouico? how does my little Mirror of Knight-hood? this is kindly done yfaith: welcome by my troth.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: And how doest, frolicke? Saue you faire Lady. Thou lookest smug and brauely, Noble Mat.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Drinke and feed, laugh and lie warme.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Is this thy wife?

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: A poore Gentlewoman, sir, whom I make vse of a nights.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Pay custome to your lips, sweet Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: Borrow some shells of him, some wine, sweet heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Ile send for't then yfaith.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: You send for't? Some wine I prethee.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: I ha no money.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: S'blood, nor I: What wine loue you, Signior?

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: Here, or Ile not stay, I protest; trouble the Gentle∣woman too much?
SP.L: And what newes flies abroad, Matheo?

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: Troth, none. Oh Signior, we ha beene merry in our daies.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: And no doubt shall agen.
The Diuine powers neuer shoot Darts at men
Mortall, to kill them.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: You say true.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Why should we grieue at want?
Say the world made thee her Minnion, that
Thy head lay in her lap, and that she danc't thee
On her wanton knee, she could but giue thee a whole
World: that's all, and that all's nothing; the worlds
Greatest part cannot fill vp one corner of thy heart.
Say, the three corners were all filld, alas!
Of what art thou possest, a thinne blowne glasse:
Such as by Boyes is puft into the aire.
Were twenty Kingdomes thine, thou'dst liue in care:
Thou could'st not sleepe the better, nor liue longer,
Nor merrier be, nor healthfuller, nor stronger.
If then thou want'st, thus make that want thy pleasure,
No man wants all things, nor has all in measure.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: I am the most wretched fellow: sure some left∣handed Priest christned me, I am so vnlucky: I am neuer out of one puddle or another, still falling.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Fill out wine to my little finger.
With my heart yfaith.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Thankes, good Matheo.
To your owne sweet selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.P: All the Brokers hearts, sir, are made of flint, I can with all my knocking, strike but sixe sparkes of fire out of them, here's sixe duckets, if youle take them.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: Giue me them: an euill conscience gnaw them all, moths and plagues hang vpon their lowsie wardrobs.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Is this your man, Matheo? An old Seruingman.

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.L: You may giue me t'other halfe too, sir:
That's the Begger.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: What hast there, gold?

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: A sort of Rascalls are in my debt, (God knowes what) and they feed me with bits, with crummes, a pox choke them.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: A word, Matheo: be not angry with me,
Beleeue it that I know the touch of time,
And can part copper (tho it be gilded o're)
From the true gold: the sailes which thou doest spread,
Would show well, if they were not borrowed.
The sound of thy low fortunes drew me hither,
I giue my selfe vnto thee, prethee vse me,
I will bestow on you a suite of Sattin,
And all things else to fit a Gentleman,
Because I loue you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Thankes, good Noble Knight.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Call on me when you please,
Till then farewell.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Hast angled? hast cut vp this fresh Salmon?

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Wudst haue me be so base?

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: It's base to steale, it's base to be a whore:
Thou't be more base, Ile make thee keepe a doore.

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.P: I hope he will not sneake away with all the money, will he?

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Thou seest he does.

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.P: Nay then it's well. I set my braines vpon an vpright Last; tho my wits be old, yet they are like a witherd pip∣pin, wholsome. Looke you, Mistris, I told him I had but sixe duckets of the (Knaue) Broker, but I had eight, and kept these two for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Thou shouldst haue giuen him all.

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.L: What, to flie hie?

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Like waues, my misery driues on misery.

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.P: Sell his wiues cloathes from her backe? does any Poulterers wife pull chickins aliue? He Riots all abroad, wants all at home; he Dices, whores, swaggers, sweares, cheates, borrowes, pawnes: Ile giue him hooke and line, a little more for all this.
SP.L: Yet sure i'th end he'll delude all my hopes,
And shew me a French tricke danc'd on the ropes.
SP.STAGE: Enter at one doore Lodouico and Carolo; at another Bots, and Mistris Horsleach; Candido and his wife appeare in the Shop.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Hist, hist, Lieutenant Bots, how do'st, man?

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.L: Whither are you ambling, Madam Horsleach?

SP.SPEAKER: Hors.
SP.L: About worldly profit, sir: how doe your Worships?

SP.SPEAKER: Bots.
SP.P: We want tooles, Gentlemen, to furnish the trade: they weare out day and night, they weare out till no mettle bee left in their backe; wee heare of two or three new Wenches are come vp with a Carrier, and your old Goshawke here is flying at them.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: And faith, what flesh haue you at home?

SP.SPEAKER: Hors.
SP.P: Ordinary Dishes, by my troth, sweet men, there's few good i'th Cittie; I am as well furnisht as any, and tho I say it, as well custom'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Bots.
SP.P: We haue meates of all sorts of dressing; we haue stew'd meat for your Frenchmen, pretty light picking meat for your Italian, and that which is rotten roasted, for Don Spaniardo.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: A pox on't.

SP.SPEAKER: Bots.
SP.P: We haue Poulterers ware for your sweet bloods, as Doue, Chickin, Ducke, Teale, Woodcocke, and so forth: and Butchers meat for the Cittizen: yet Muttons fall very bad this yeere.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: Stay, is not that my patient Linnen Draper yonder, and my fine yong smug Mistris, his wife?

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: Sirra Grannam, Ile giue thee for thy fee twenty crownes, if thou canst but procure me the wearing of yon veluet cap.

SP.SPEAKER: Hos.
SP.P: You'd weare another thing besides the cap. Y'are a Wag.

SP.SPEAKER: Boss.
SP.P: Twenty crownes? we'li share, and Ile be your pully to draw her on.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Doo't presently; we'll ha some sport.

SP.SPEAKER: Hors.
SP.P: Wheele you about, sweet men: doe you see, Ile chea∣pen wares of the man, whilest Bots is doing with his wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: Too't: if we come into the shop to doe you grace, wee'll call you Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Bots.
SP.P: Pox a your old face, giue it the badge of all scuruy faces, a Masque.

SP.SPEAKER: Cand.
SP.P: What is't you lacke, Gentlewoman? Cambricke or Lawnes, or fine Hollands? Pray draw neere, I can sell you a penny-worth.

SP.SPEAKER: Bots.
SP.L: Some Cambricke for my old Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Cand.
SP.L: Cambricke? you shall, the purest thred in Millan.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod. and Car.
SP.L: Saue you, Signior Candido.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: How does my Noble Master? how my faire Mistris?

SP.SPEAKER: Cand.
SP.P: My Worshipfull good Seruant, view it well, for 'tis both fine and euen.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: Cry you mercy, Madam, tho mask'd, I thought it should be you by your man. Pray' Signior, shew her the best, for she commonly deales for good ware.

SP.SPEAKER: Cand.
SP.L: Then this shall fit her, this is for your Ladiship.

SP.SPEAKER: Bots.
SP.P: A word, I pray, there is a waiting Gentlewomon of my Ladies: her name is Ruyna, saies she's your Kinswoman, and that you should be one of her Aunts.

SP.SPEAKER: Wife.
SP.L: One of her Aunts? troth sir, I know her not.

SP.SPEAKER: Bots.
SP.P: If it please you to bestow the poore labour of your legs at any time, I will be your conuoy thither?

SP.SPEAKER: Wife.
SP.P: I am a Snaile, sir, seldome leaue my house, if't please her to visit me, she shall be welcome.

SP.SPEAKER: Bots.
SP.P: Doe you heare? the naked troth is: my Lady hath a yong Knight, her sonne, who loues you, y'are made, if you lay hold vpont: this Iewell he sends you.

SP.SPEAKER: Wife.
SP.P: Sir, I returne his loue and Iewell with scorne; let goe my hand, or I shall call my husband. You are an arrant Knaue.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: What, will she doe?

SP.SPEAKER: Bots.
SP.P: Doe? they shall all doe if Bots sets vpon them once, she was as if she had profest the trade, squeamish at first, at last I shewed her this Iewell, said, a Kuight sent it her.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Is't gold, and right stones?

SP.SPEAKER: Bots.
SP.L: Copper, Copper, I goe a fishing with these baites.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: She nibbled, but wud not swallow the hooke, because the Cunger-head her husband was by: but shee bids the Gentleman name any afternoone, and she'll meet him at her Garden house, which I know.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Is this no lie now?

SP.SPEAKER: Bots.
