SP.L: Dam me if—

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Oh prethee stay there.

SP.SPEAKER: Bots.
SP.L: The twenty crownes, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: Before he has his worke done? but on my Knightly word, he shall pay't thee.
SP.STAGE: Enter Astolpho, Beraldo, Fontinell, and the Irish Footman.

SP.SPEAKER: Asto.
SP.P: I thought thou hadst beene gone into thine owne Country.

SP.SPEAKER: Bry.
SP.L: No faat la, I cannot goe dis foure or tree dayes.

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.P: Looke thee, yonders the shop, and that's the man himselfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Fon.
SP.P: Thou shalt but cheapen, and doe as we told thee, to put a iest vpon him, to abuse his patience.

SP.SPEAKER: Bry.
SP.P: I faat, I doubt my pate shall be knocked: but sa crees sa me, for your shakes, I will runne to any Linnen Draper in hell, come preddy.

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes.
SP.L: Saue you Gallants.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod. and Car.
SP.L: Oh, well met!

SP.SPEAKER: Cand.
SP.L: You'll giue no more you say? I cannot take it.

SP.SPEAKER: Hors.
SP.L: Truly Ile giue no more.

SP.SPEAKER: Cand.
SP.P: It must not fetch it. What wud you haue, sweet Gentlemen?

SP.SPEAKER: Asto.
SP.L: Nay, here's the Customer.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: The Garden-house you say? wee'll boult out your roguery.

SP.SPEAKER: Cand.
SP.P: I will but lay these parcels by—My men are all at Custome-house vnloding Wares, if Cambricke you wud deale in, there's the best, all Millan cannot sample it.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: Doe you heare? 1. 2. 3. S'foot, there came in 4. Gallants, sure your wife is slipt vp, and the 4th. man I hold my life, is grafting your Warden tree.

SP.SPEAKER: Cand.
SP.L: Ha, ha, ha: you Gentlemen are full of Iest.
If she be vp, she's gone some wares to show,
I haue aboue as good wares as below.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Haue you so? nay then—

SP.SPEAKER: Cand.
SP.L: Now Gentlemen, is't Cambricks?

SP.SPEAKER: Bry.
SP.L: I predee now let me haue de best wares.

SP.SPEAKER: Cand.
SP.L: What's that he saies, pray 'Gentlemen?

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Mary he saies we are like to haue the best wares.

SP.SPEAKER: Cand.
SP.P: The best wares? all are bad, yet wares doe good, And like to Surgeons, let sicke Kingdomes blood.

SP.SPEAKER: Bry.
SP.P: Faat a Deuill pratest tow so, a pox on dee, I preddee let me see some Hollen, to make Linnen shirts, for feare my body be lowsie.

SP.SPEAKER: Cand.
SP.L: Indeed I vnderstand no word he speakes.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: Mary, he saies, that at the siege in Holland there was much bawdry vsed among the Souldiers, tho they were lowsie.

SP.SPEAKER: Cand.
SP.L: It may be so, that's likely, true indeed,
In euery garden, sir, does grow that weed.

SP.SPEAKER: Bry.
SP.P: Pox on de gardens, and de weedes, and de fooles cap dere, and de cloutes; heare? doest make a Hobby-horse of me.

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes.
SP.L: Oh fie, he has torne de Cambricke.

SP.SPEAKER: Cand.
SP.L: 'Tis no matter.

SP.SPEAKER: Asto.
SP.L: It frets me to the soule.

SP.SPEAKER: Cand.
SP.L: So doest not me.
My Customers doe oft for remnants call,
These are two remnants now, no losse at all.
But let me tell you, were my Seruants here,
It would ha cost more.—Thanke you Gentlemen,
I vse you well, pray know my shop agen.

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes.
SP.L: Ha, ha, ha; come, come, let's goe, let's goe.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: How am I suited, Front? am I not gallant, ha?

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Yes, sir, you are suited well.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Exceeding passing well, and to the time.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: The Taylor has plaid his part with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: And I haue plaid a Gentlemans part with my Tay∣lor, for I owe him for the making of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: And why did you so, sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P:
To keepe the fashion; It's your onely fashion now of your best ranke of Gallants, to make their Taylors waite
for their money, neither were it wisedome indeed to pay them vpon the first edition of a new suite: for commonly the suite is owing for, when the lynings are worne out, and there's no reason then, that the Taylor should be paid be∣fore the Mercer.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Is this the suite the Knight bestowed vpon you?

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: This is the suite, and I need not shame to weare it, for better men then I would be glad to haue suites bestow∣ed on them. It's a generous fellow,—but—pox on him—we whose Pericranions are the very Limbecks and Stillitories of good wit, and flie hie, must driue liquor out of stale ga∣ping Oysters. Shallow Knight, poore Squire Tinacheo: Ile make a wild Cataine of forty such: hang him, he's an Asse, he's alwaies sober.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: This is your fault to wound your friends still.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: No faith, Front, Lodouico is a noble Slauonian: it's more rare to see him in a womans company, then for a Spa∣niard to goe into England, and to challenge the English Fen∣cers there.—One knockes,—See—La, fa, sol, la, fa, la, rustle in Silkes and Satins: there's musique in this, and a Taffety Petticoate, it make both flie hie,—Catzo.
SP.STAGE: Enter Bellafront, after her Orlando like himselfe, with foure men after him.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Matheo? 'tis my Father.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: Ha, Father? It's no matter, hee findes no tatterd Prodigals here.

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.P: Is not the doore good enough to hold your blue Coates? away, Knaues. Weare not your cloathes thred-bare at knees for me; beg Heauens blessing, (not mine.) Oh cry your Worship mercy, sir, was somewhat bold to talke to this Gentlewoman, your wife here.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: A poore Gentlewoman, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.L: Stand not, sir, bare to me; I ha read oft
That Serpents who creepe low, belch ranker poison
That winged Dragons doe, that flie aloft.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: If it offend you, sir? 'tis for my pleasure.

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.L: Your pleasure be't, sir; vmh, is this your Palace?

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Yes, and our Kingdome, for 'tis our content.

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.P: It's a very poore Kingdome then; what, are all your Subiects gone a Sheepe-shearing? not a Maid? not a Man? not so much as a Cat? you keepe a good house belike, iust like one of your profession, euery roome with bare walls, and a halfe-headed bed to vault vpon (as all your bawdy∣houses are.) Pray who are your Vpholsters? Oh, the Spider. I see, they bestow hangings vpon you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Bawdy-house? Zounds sir—

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Oh sweet Matheo, peace. Vpon my knees
I doe beseech you, sir, not to arraigne me
For sinnes, which heauen, I hope, long since hath pardoned.
Those flames (like lightning flashes) are so spent,
The heate no more remaines, then where ships went,
Or where birds cut the aire, the print remaines.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Pox on him, kneele to a Dog?

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: She that's a Whore,
Liues gallant, fares well, is not (like me) poore,
I ha now as small acquaintance with that sinne,
As if I had neuer knowne it; that, neuer bin.

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.P: No acquaintance with it? what maintaines thee then? how doest liue then? has thy husband any Lands? any Rents comming in, any Stocke going, any Ploughs iogging, any Ships sailing? hast thou any Wares to turne, so much as to get a single penny by? yes, thou hast Ware to sell, Knaues are thy Chapmen, and thy Shop is Hell.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Doe you heare, sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.L: So sir, I do heare, sir, more of you then you dreame I do.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: You flie a little too hie, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.L: Why, sir, too hie?

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: I ha suffred your tongue, like a bard Cater tra, to runne all this while, and ha not stopt it.

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.L: Well, sir, you talke like a Gamester.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: If you come to bark at her, because shee's a poore rogue; look you, here's a fine path, sir, and there, there the doore.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Matheo?

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Your blue Coates stay for you, sir.
I loue a good honest roaring Boy, and so—

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.L: That's the Deuill.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: Sir, sir, Ile ha no Ioues in my house to thunder A∣uaunt: she shall liue and be maintained, when you, like a keg of musty Sturgeon, shall stinke. Where? in your Coffin. How? be a musty fellow, and lowsie.

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.P: I know she shall be maintained, but how? she like a Queane, thou like a Knaue; she like a Whore, thou like a Thiefe.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Theife? Zounds Thiefe?

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Good dearest Mat.—Father.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: Pox on you both, Ile not be braued: New Sattin scornes to be put downe with bare bawdy Veluet. Thiefe?

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.P: I Thiefe, th'art a Murtherer, a Cheater, a Whore-monger, a Pot-hunter, a Borrower, a Begger—

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Deare Father.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: An old Asse, a Dog, a Churle, a Chuffe, an Vsurer, a Villaine, a Moth, a mangy Mule, with an old veluet foot-cloth on his backe, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Oh me!

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.L: Varlet, for this Ile hang thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Ha, ha, alas.

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.L: Thou keepest a man of mine here, vnder my nose.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Vnder thy beard.

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.P: As arrant a smell-smocke, for an old Mutton-munger, as thy selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: No, as your selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.P: As arrant a purse-take. as euer cride, Stand, yet a good fellow, I confesse, and valiant, but he'll bring thee to'th Gallowes; you both haue robd of late two poore Country Pedlers.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: How's this? how's this? doest thou flie hie? rob Pedlers? beare witnes Front, rob Pedlers? my man and I a Thiefe?

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Oh, sir, no more.

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.P: I Knaue, two Pedlers, hue and cry is vp, Warrants are out, and I shall see thee climbe a Ladder.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat
SP.P: And come downe againe as well as a Bricklayer, or a Tyler. How the vengeance knowes he this? If I be han∣ged, Ile tell the people I married old Friscabaldoes Daughter, Ile frisco you, and your old carkas.

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.P: Tell what thou canst; if I stay here longer, I shall bee hang'd too, for being in thy company; therefore, as I found you, I leaue you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Kneele, and get money of him.

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.P: A Knaue and a Queane, a Thiefe and a Strumpet, a couple of Beggers, a brace of Baggages.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: Hang vpon him. I, I, sir, fare you well; we are so: follow close—we are Beggers—in Sattin—to him.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Is this your comfort, when so many yeeres
You ha left me frozen to death?

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.L: Freeze still, starue still.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Yes, so I shall: I must: I must and will.
If as you say I'm poore, relieue me then,
Let me not sell my body to base men.
You call me Strumpet, Heauen knowes I am none:
Your cruelty may driue me to be one:
Let not that sinne be yours, let not the shame
Of common Whore liue longer then my name.
That cunning Bawd (Necessity) night and day
Plots to vndoe me; driue that Hag away,
Lest being at lowest ebbe, as now I am,
I sinke for euer.

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.L: Lowest ebbe, what ebbe?

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: So poore, that (tho to tell it be my shame)
I am not worth a dish to hold my meate;
I am yet poorer, I want bread to eate.

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.L: It's not seene by your cheekes.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: I thinke she has read an Homely to tickle to the old rogue.

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.L: Want bread? there's Sattin: bake that.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: S'blood, make Pasties of my cloathes?

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.P: A faire new Cloake, stew that; an excellent gilt Ra∣pier.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Will you eat that, sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.L: I could feast ten good fellowes with those Hangers.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: The pox you shall.

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.L: I shall not (till thou beggest,) thinke thou art poore;
And when thou beggest, Ile feed thee at my doore,
As I feed Dogs, (with bones) till then beg,
Borrow, pawne, steale, and hang, turne Bawde.
When th'art no Whore, my heart-strings sure
Would crack, were they strained more.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: This is your Father, your damn'd—confusion light vpon all the generation of you; he can come bragging hither with foure white Herrings (at's taile) in blue Coates without roes in their bellies, but I may starue ere he giue me so much as a cob.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: What tell you me of this? alas.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: Goe trot after your Dad, doe you capitulate, Ile pawne not for you, Ile not steale to be hanged for such an hypocriticall close common Harlot: away, you Dog—Braue yfaith! Vds foot, Giue me some meate.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Yes, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: Goodman slaue, my man too, is gallop'd to the De∣uill athe t'other side: Pacheco, Ile checo you. Is this your Dads day? England (they say) is the onely hell for Horses, and onely Paradise for Women: pray get you to that Paradise, because y'are called an Honest Whore; there they liue none but honest whores with a pox: Mary here in our Citty, all our sex are but foot-cloth Nags: the Master no sooner lights, but the man leapes into the saddle.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Will you sit downe I pray, sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P:
I could teare (by'th Lord) his flesh, and eate his midriffe in salt, as I eate this:—must I choake—my Father Friscabaldo, I shall make a pittifull Hog-louse of you Orlando, if you fall once into my fingers—Here's the sauo∣rest
meat: I ha got a stomacke with chasing. What Rogue should tell him of those two Pedlers? A plague choake him, and gnaw him to the bare bones: come fill.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.P: Thou sweatest with very anger, good sweet, vex not, 'las, 'tis no fault of mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: Where didst buy this Mutton? I neuer felt better ribbes.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: A neighbour sent it me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: Hah, neighbour? foh, my mouth stinkes, you whore, doe you beg victuals for me? Is this Sattin doublet to bee bumbasted with broken meat?

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.L: What will you doe, sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Beat out the braines of a beggerly—

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.P: Beat out an Asses head of your owne; away, Mistris. Zownds, doe but touch one haire of her, and Ile so quilt your cap with old Iron, that your coxcombe shall ake the worse these seuen yeeres for't: Does she looke like a roasted Rabbet, that you must haue the head for the braines?

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: Ha, ha: Goe out of my doores, you Rogue, away, foure markes trudge.

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.P: Foure markes? no, sir, my twenty pound that you ha made flie hie, and I am gone.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: Must I be fed with chippings? y'are best get a clap∣dish, and say y'are Proctor to some Spittle-house. Where hast thou beene, Pacheco? come hither my little Turky∣cocke.

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.L: I cannot abide, sir, to see a woman wrong'd, not I.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Sirra, here was my Father-in-law to day.

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.L: Pish, then y'are full of Crownes.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: Hang him, he would ha thrust crownes vpon me, to haue falne in againe, but I scorne cast-cloathes, or any mans gold.

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.L: But mine: how did he brooke that (sir?)

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: Oh: swore like a dozen of drunken Tinkers; at last growing foule in words, he and foure of his men drew vp∣on me, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.L: In your house? wud I had bin by.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: I made no more adoe, but fell to my old locke, and so thrashed my blue Coates, and old crabtree-face my fa∣ther-in-law, and then walkt like a Lion in my grate.

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.L: Oh Noble Master!

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: Sirra, he could tell me of the robbing the two Pedlers, and that warrants are out for vs both.

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.L: Good, sir, I like not those crackers.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Crack halter, wut set thy foot to mine?

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.L: How, sir? at drinking.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: We'll pull that old Crow my Father: rob thy Ma∣ster. I know the house, thou the seruants: the purchase is rich, the plot to get it easie, the Dog will not part from a bone.

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.P: Pluck't out of his throat then: Ile snarle for one, if this can bite.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: Say no more, say no more, old cole, meet me anon at the signe of the Shipwracke.

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.L: Yes, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: And dost heare, man?—the Shipwracke.

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.L: Th'art at the Shipwracke now, and like a swimmer
Bold (but vnexpert) with those waues doest play,
Whose dalliance (whorelike) is to cast thee away.

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.L: And here's another Vessell, (better fraught,
But as ill man'd) her sinking will be wraught,
If rescue come not: like a Man of warre
Ile therefore brauely out: somewhat Ile doe,
And either saue them both, or perish too.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: It is my fate to be bewitched by those eyes.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Fate? your folly.
Why should my face thus mad you? 'las, those colours
Are wound vp long agoe, which beauty spred,
The flowres that once grew here, are withered.
You turn'd my blacke soule white, made it looke new,
And should I sinne, it ne'r should be with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Your hand, Ile offer you faire play: When first
We met i'th Lists together, you remember
You were a common Rebell; with one parlee
I won you to come in.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: You did.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Ile try
If now I can beate downe this Chastity
With the same Ordnance; will you yeeld this Fort,
If with the power of Argument now (as then)
I get of you the conquest: as before
I turnd you honest, now to turne you whore,
By force of strong perswasion?

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.L: If you can,
I yeeld.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: The allarm's strucke vp: I'm your man.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: A woman giues defiance.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Sit.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Beginne:
'Tis a braue battaile to encounter sinne.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: You men that are to fight in the same warre,
To which I'm prest, and pleade at the same barre,
To winne a woman, if you wud haue me speed,
Send all your wishes.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: No doubt y'are heard, proceede.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: To be a Harlot, that you stand vpon,
The very name's a charme to make you one.
Harlot was a Dame of so diuine
And rauishing touch, that she was Concubine
To an English King: her sweet bewitching eye
Did the Kings heart-strings in such loue-knots tye,
That euen the coyest was proud when she could heare
Men say, Behold; another Harlot there;
And after her all women that were faire
Were Harlots call'd, as to this day some are:
Besides her dalliance, she so well does mix,
That she's in Latine call'd the Meretrix.
Thus for the name; for the profession, this,
Who liues in bondage, liues lac'd, the chiefe blisse
This world below can yeeld, is liberty:
And who (than whores) with looser wings dare flie?
As Iunoes proud bird spreads the fairest taile,
So does a Strumpet hoist the loftiest saile.
She's no mans slaue; (men are her slaues) her eye
Moues not on wheeles screwd vp with Iealowsie.
She (Horst, or Coacht) does merry iourneys make,
Free as the Sunne in his gilt Zodiake:
As brauely does she shine, as fast she's driuen,
But staies not long in any house of Heauen:
But shifts from Signe, to Signe, her amorous prizes
More rich being when she's downe, then when she rizes.
In briefe, Gentlemen haunt them, Soldiers fight for them,
Few men but know them, few or none abhorre them:
Thus (for sport sake) speake I, as to a woman,
Whom (as the worst ground) I would turne to common:
But you I would enclose for mine owne bed.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: So should a husband be dishonoured.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Dishonoured? not a whit: to fall to one
(Besides your husband) is to fall to none,
For one no number is.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Faith, should you take
One in your bed, would you that reckoning make?
'Tis time you sound retreate.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Say, haue I wonne,
Is the day ours?

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: The battaile's but halfe done,
None but your selfe haue yet sounded alarmes,
Let vs strike too, else you dishonour armes.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: If you can win the day,
The glorie's yours.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: To proue a woman should not be a whore,
When she was made, she had one man, and no more,
Yet she was tied to lawes then, for (ouen than)
'Tis said, she was not made for men, but man.
Anon, t'increase earths brood, the law was varied,
Men should take many wiues: and tho they married
According to that Act, yet 'tis not knowne,
But that those wiues were onely tied to one.
New Parliaments were since: for now one woman
Is shared betweene three hundred, nay she's common;
Common? as spotted Leopards, whom for sport
Men hunt, to get the flesh, but care not for't.
So spread they Nets of gold, and tune their Calls,
To inchaunt silly women to take falls:
Swearing they are Angels, (which that they may win)
They'll hire the Deuill to come with false Dice in.
Oh Sirens suttle tunes! your selues you flatter,
And our weake sex betray, so men loue water;
It serues to wash their hands, but (being once foule)
The water downe is powred, cast out of doores,
And euen of such base vse doe men make whores.
A Harlot (like a Hen) more sweetnes reapes,
To picke men one by one vp, then in heapes:
Yet all feeds but confounding. Say you should taste me,
I serue but for the time, and when the day
Of warre is done, am casheerd out of pay:
If like lame Soldiers I could beg, that's all,
And there's lusts Rendez-vous, an Hospitall.
Who then would be a mans slaue, a mans woman?
She's halfe starn'd the first day that feeds in Common.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: You should not feed so, but with me alone.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: If I drinke poison by stealth, is't not all one?
Is't not ranke poison still? with you alone!
Nay say you spide a Curtezan, whose soft side
To touch, you'd sell your birth-right for one kisse,
Be rack'd, she's won, y'are sated: what followes this?
Oh, then you curse that Bawd that toald you in,
(The Night) you curse your lust, you loath the sin,
You loath her very sight, and ere the day
Arise, you rise glad when y'are stolne away.
Euen then when you are drunke with all her sweets,
There's no true pleasure in a Strumpets sheetes.
Women, whom Lust so prostitutes to sale,
Like Dancers vpon ropes; once seene, are stale.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: If all the threds of Harlots lyues are span,
So coorse as you would make them, tell me why
You so long loued the trade?

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: If all the threds
Of Harlots lyues be fine as you would make them,
Why doe not you perswade your wife turne whore,
And all Dames else to fall befere that sin?
Like an ill husband (ho I knew the same,
To be my vndoing) followed I that game.
Oh when the worke of Lust had earn'd my bread,
To taste it, how I trembled, lest each bit,
Ere it went downe, should choake me (chewing it?)
My bed seem'd like a Cabin hung in Hell,
The Bawde Hells Porter, and the lickorish wine
The Pander fetch'd, was like an easie Fine,
For which, me thought I leas'd away my soule,
And oftentimes (euen in my quaffing bowle)
Thus said I to my selfe, I am a whore,
And haue drunke downe thus much confusion more.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: It is a common rule, and 'tis most true,
Two of one trade neuer loue; no more doe you.
Why are you sharpe 'gainst that you once profest?

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Why doate you on that, which you did once detest?
I cannot (seeing she's wouen of such bad stuffe)
Set colours on a Harlot base enough.
Nothing did make me, when I loued them best,
To loath them more then this: when in the street
A faire yong modest Damsell I did meet,
She seem'd to all a Doue (when I pass'd by)
And I (to all) a Rauen: euery eye
That followed her, wont with a bash full glance
At me, each bold and ieering countenance
Darted forth scorne: to her (as if she had bin
Some Tower vnvanquished) would they vaile,
'Gainst me swolne Rumor hoisted euery saile.
She (crown'd with reuerend praises) passed by them,
I (tho with face maskt) could not scape the hem,
For (as if Heauen had set strange markes on Whores,
Because they should be pointing stocks to man)
Drest vp in ciuilest shape a Curtizan.
Let her walke Saint-like, notelesse, and vnknowne,
Yet she's betraid by some tricke of her owne.
Were Harlots therefore wise, they'd be sold deare:
For men account them good but for one yeere:
And then like Almanackes (whose dates are gone)
They are throwne by, and no more lookt vpon.
Who'le therefore backward fall, who will lanch forth
In Seas so foule, for ventures no more worth?
Lusts voiage hath (if not this course) this crosse,
Buy ne'r so cheape, your Ware comes home with losse.
What, shall I sound retreat? the battaile's done:
Let the world iudge which of vs two haue won.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: I!

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: You? nay then as cowards doe in fight,
What by blowes cannot, shall be saued by flight.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Flie to earths fixed Center: to the Caues
Of euerlasting horror, Ile pursue thee,
(Tho loaden with sinnes) euen to Hells brazen doores.
Thus wisest men turne fooles, doting on whores.
SP.STAGE: Enter the Duke, Lodouico, and Orlando: after them Infaelice. Carolo, Astolfo, Beraldo, Fontinell.

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.P: I beseech your Grace (tho your eye be so piercing) as vnder a poore blue Coate, to cull out an honest Father from an old Seruingman: yet good my Lord discouer not the plot to any, but onely this Gentleman that is now to be an Actor in our ensuing Comedy.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Thou hast thy wish, Orlando, passe vnknowne,
Sforsa shall onely goe along with thee,
To see that Warrant serued vpon thy Sonne.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: To attach him vpon fellony, for 2. Pedlers: is't not so?

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.P: Right, my Noble Knight: those Pedlers were two Knaues of mine; he fleec'd the men before, and now he pur∣poses to flea the Master. He will rob me, his teeth water to be nibbling at my gold, but this shal hang him by'th gills, till I pull him on shore.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Away: ply you the businesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.P: Thankes to your Grace: but my good Lord, for my Daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: You know what I haue said.

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.P: And remember what I haue sworne: She's more ho∣nest, on my soule, then one of the Turkes Wenches, watcht by a hundred Eunuches.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: So she had need, for the Turkes make them whores.

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.P: He's a Turke that makes any woman a Whore, hee's no true Christian I'm sure. I commit your Grace.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Infaelice.

SP.SPEAKER: Infae.
SP.L: Here, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Signior Friscabaldo.

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.L: Frisking agen, Pacheco?

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: Vds so, Pacheco? wee'll haue some sport with this Warrant: 'tis to apprehend all suspected persons in the house: Besides, there's one Bots a Pander, and one Madam Horsleach a Bawde, that haue abus'd my friend, those two Coneyes will we ferret into the pursenet.

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.P: Let me alone for dabbing them o'th necke: come, come.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Doe ye heare, Gallants? meet me anon at Matheos.

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes.
SP.L: Enough.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Th' old Fellow sings that note thou didst before,
Onely his tunes are, that she is no Whore,
But that she sent his Letters and his gifts,
Out of a Noble Triumph o're his Lust,
To shew she trampled his Assaults in dust.

SP.SPEAKER: Infae.
SP.L: 'Tis a good honest seruant, that old man.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: I doubt no lesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Infae.
SP.L: And it may be my husband,
Because when once this woman was vnmaskt,
He leueld all her thoughts, and made them fit:
Now he'd marre all agen, to try his wit.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: It may be so too, for to turne a Harlot
Honest, it must be by strong Antidots,
'Tis rare, as to see Panthers change their spots.
And when she's once a Starre (fixed) and shines bright,
Tho 'twere impiety then to dim her light,
Because we see such Tapers seldome burne.
Yet 'tis the pride and glory of some men,
To change her to a blazing Starre agen,
And it may be, Hipollito does no more.
It cannot be, but y'are acquainted all
With that same madnesse of our Sonne-in-law,
That dotes so on a Curtizan.

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes.
SP.L: Yes, my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.L: All the City thinkes he's a Whoremonger.

SP.SPEAKER: Ast.
SP.L: Yet I warrant, he'll sweare, no man markes him.

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.P: 'Tis like so, for when a man goes a wenching, is as if he had a strong stincking breath, euery one smells him out, yet he feeles it not, tho it be rancker then the sweat of six∣teene Bearewarders.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: I doubt then you haue all those stinking breaths,
You might be all smelt out.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: Troth my Lord, I thinke we are all as you ha bin in your youth when you went a Maying, we all loue to heare the Cuckoo sing vpon other mens Trees.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: It's well yet you confesse: but Girle, thy bed
Shall not be parted with a Curtizan—'tis strange,
No frowne of mine, no frowne of the poore Lady,
(My abused child, his wife) no care of fame,
Of Honor, Heauen or Hell, no not that name
Of Common Strumpet, can affright, or woo
Him to abandon her; the Harlot does vndoe him,
She has bewitched him, robd him of his shape,
Turnd him into a beast, his reason's lost,
You see he lookes wild, does he not?

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.L: I ha noted new Moones
In's face, my Lord, all full of change.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: He's no more life vnto Hipollito,
Then dead men are to liuing—neuer sleepes,
Or if he doe, it's dreames; and in those dreames
His armes worke,—and then cries—Sweet—what's her
Name, what's the drabs name?

SP.SPEAKER: Ast.
SP.L: In troth, my Lord, I know not,
I know no drabs, not I.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Oh, Bellafront!
And catching her fast, cries, My Bellafront.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: A drench that's able to kill a Horse, cannot kill this disease of Smock-smelling, my Lord, if it haue once eaten deepe.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Ile try all Phisicke, and this Med'cine first:
I haue directed Warrants strong and peremptory
(To purge our Citty Millan, and to cure the outward
Parts, the Suburbes) for the attaching
Of all those women, who (like gold) want waight,
Citties (like Ships) should haue no idle fraight.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.L: No, my Lord, and light wenches are no idle fraight,
But what's your Graces reach in this?

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: This (Carolo.) If she whom my Son doates on,
Be in that Master-booke enrold, he'll shame
Euer t' approach one of such noted name.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.L: But say she be not?

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Yet on Harlots heads
New Lawes shall fall so heauy, and such blowes shall
Giue to those that haunt them, that Hipollito
(If not for feare of Law) for loue to her,
If he loue truely, shall her bed forbeare.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: Attach all the light heeles i'th Citty, and clap em vp? why, my Lord? you diue into a Well vnsearchable: all the Whores within the walls, & without the walls? I would not be he should meddle with them for ten such Dukedomes; the Army that you speake on, is able to fill all the prisons within this Citty, and to leaue not a drinking roome in any Tauerne besides.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Those onely shall be caught that are of note,
Harlots in each street flow:
The fish being thus i'th net, our selfe will sit,
And with eye most seuere dispose of it.—come, Girle.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.L: Araigne the poore Whore.

SP.SPEAKER: Ast.
SP.L: Ile not misse that Sessions.

SP.SPEAKER: Font.
SP.L: Nor I.

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.L: Nor I,
Tho I hold vp my hand there my selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: Let who will come (my Noble Shauileir) I can but play the kind Hoast, and bid vm welcome.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: We'll trouble your house (Matheo) but as Dutchmen doe in Tauernes (drinke, be merry, and be gone.)

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.P: Indeed if you be right Dutchmen, if you fall to drink∣ing, you must be gone.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: The worst is, my wife is not at home; but we'll flie hie (my generous Knight) for all that: there's no Musike when a woman is in the consort.

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.L: No, for she's like a paire of Virginals,
Alwaies with Iackes at her taile.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: See, the Couy is sprung.

SP.SPEAKER: O.
SP.L: Saue you Gallants.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Happily encounterd, sweet bloods.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: Gentlemen, you all know Signior Candido, the Linnen Draper, he that's more patient then a browne Baker, vpon the day when he heates his Ouen, and has forty Scolds a∣bout him.

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes.
SP.L: Yes, we know him all, what of him?

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: Wud it not be a good fit of mirth, to make a piece of English cloth of him, and to stretch him on the Tainters, till the threds of his owne naturall humor cracke, by ma∣king him drinke healths, Tobacco, dance, sing bawdy songs, or to run any bias according as we thinke good to cast him?

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.L: 'Twere a Morris dance worth the seeing.

SP.SPEAKER: Ast.
SP.P: But the old Fox is so crafty, we shall hardly hunt out of his den.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: To that traine I ha giuen fire already; and the hook to draw him hither, is to see certaine pieces of Lawne, which I told him I haue to sell, and indeed haue such: fetch them downe, Pacheco.

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.P: Yes, sir, I'm your Water-spanniell, and will fetch any thing: but Ile fetch one dish of meat anon, shall turne your stomacke, and that's a Constable.

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes.
SP.L: How now? how now?

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.L: What Gally-foist is this?

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: Peace, two dishes of stew'd prunes, a Bawde and a Pander. My worthy Lieutenant Bots; why, now I see th'art a-man of thy word, welcome; welcome Mistris Horsleach: Pray Gentlemen, salute this reuerend Matron.

SP.SPEAKER: Hors.
SP.L: Thankes to all your Worships.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: I-bade a Drawer send in wine too: did none come along with thee (Grannam) but the Lieutenant?

SP.SPEAKER: Hors.
SP.P: None came along with me but Bots, if it like your Worship.

SP.SPEAKER: Bots.
SP.L: Who the pox should come along with you but Bots?

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes.
SP.L: Oh braue! march faire.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Are you come? that's well.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Here's Ordnance able to sacke a Citty.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Come, repeat, read this Inuentory.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Uint.
SP.P: Imprimis, a pottle of Greeke wine, a pottle of Peter sa meene, a pottle of Charnico, and a pottle of Zi∣attica.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Y'are paid?

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Uint.
SP.L: Yes Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: So shall some of vs be anon, I feare.

SP.SPEAKER: Bots.
SP.P:
Here's a hot day towards: but zounds, this is the
life out of which a Soldier sucks sweetnesse, when this Ar∣tillery goes off roundly, some must drop to the ground: Can∣non, Demy-cannon, Saker, and Basalisk.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Giue fire, Lieutenant.

SP.SPEAKER: Bots.
SP.P: So, so: Must I venture first vpon the breach? to you all, Gallants: Bots sets vpon you all.

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes.
SP.P: Its hard (Bots) if we pepper not you, as well as you pepper vs.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: My noble Linnen Draper! Some wine: Welcome old Lad.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Y'are welcome, Signior.

SP.SPEAKER: Cand.
SP.L: These Lawnes, sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: Presently, my man is gone for them: we ha rigged a Fleet, you see here, to saile about the world.

SP.SPEAKER: Cand.
SP.L: A dangerous Voyage, sailing in such Ships.

SP.SPEAKER: Bots.
SP.L: There's no casting ouer boord yet.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: Because you are an old Lady, I will haue you be ac∣quainted with this graue Cittizen, pray bestow your lips vpon him, and bid him welcome.

SP.SPEAKER: Hors.
SP.P: Any Cittizen shall be most welcome to me:—I haue vsed to buy ware at your shop.

SP.SPEAKER: Cand.
SP.L: It may be so, good Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Hors.
SP.P: Your Prentices know my dealings well; I trust your good wife be in good case: if it please you, beare her a token from my lips, by word of mouth.

SP.SPEAKER: Cand.
SP.P: I pray no more forsooth, 'tis very well, indeed I loue no sweet meats:—Sh'as a breath stinkes worse then fifty Polecats. Sir, a word, is she a Lady?

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: A woman of a good house, and an ancient, shee's a Bawde.

SP.SPEAKER: Cand.
SP.P: A Bawde? Sir, Ile steale hence, and see your Lawnes some other time.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: Steale out of such company? Pacheco? my man is but gone for em: Lieutenant Bots, drinke to this worthy old fellow, and teach him to flie hie.

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes.
SP.L: Swagger: and make him doo't on his knees.

SP.SPEAKER: Cand.
SP.P: How, Bots? now blesse me, what doe I with Bots? no wine in sooth, no wine, good Master Bots.

SP.SPEAKER: Bots.
SP.P: Gray-beard, Goats pizzle: 'tis a health, haue this in your guts, or this, there: I will sing a bawdy song, sir, be∣cause your vergis face is melancholly, to make liquor goe downe glib: will you fall on your maribones, and pledge this health, 'tis to my Mistris, a whore?

SP.SPEAKER: Cand.
SP.P: Here's Ratsbane vpon Ratsbane: Master Bots, I pray, sir, pardon me: you are a Soldier, presse me not to this seruice, I am old, and shoot not in such pot-gunnes.

SP.SPEAKER: Bots.
SP.L: Cap, Ile teach you.

SP.SPEAKER: Cand.
SP.P: To drinke healths, is to drinke sicknesse: Gentle∣men, pray rescue me.

SP.SPEAKER: Bots.
SP.L: Zounds, who dare?

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes.
SP.L: We shall ha stabbing then?

SP.SPEAKER: Cand.
SP.L: I ha reckonings to cast vp, good Master Bots.

SP.SPEAKER: Bots.
SP.L: This will make you cast em vp better.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Why does your hand shake so?

SP.SPEAKER: Cand.
SP.L: The palsie, Signiors, danceth in my blood.

SP.SPEAKER: Bots.
SP.P: Pipe with a pox, sir, then, or Ile make your blood dance—

SP.SPEAKER: Cand.
SP.L: Hold, hold, good Master Bots, I drinke.

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes.
SP.L: To whom?

SP.SPEAKER: Cand.
SP.L: To the old Countesse there.

SP.SPEAKER: Hors.
SP.P: To me, old Boy? this is he that neuer drunke wine: once agen too't.

SP.SPEAKER: Cand.
SP.L: With much adoe the poison is got downe,
Tho I can scarce get vp; neuer before
Dranke I a whores health, nor will neuer more.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Hast bin at Gallowes?

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.L: Yes, sir, for I make account to suffer to day.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Looke, Signior: here's the Commodity.

SP.SPEAKER: Cand.
SP.L: Your price?

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Thus.

SP.SPEAKER: Cand.
SP.L: No: too deare: thus.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: No: O fie, you must slie higher: yet take em home, trifles shall not make vs quarrell, we'll agree, you shall haue them, and a penniworth, Ile fetch money at your shop.

SP.SPEAKER: Cand.
SP.L: Be it so, good Signior, send me going.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Going? a deepe bowle of wine for Signior Candido.

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.L: He wud be going.

SP.SPEAKER: Cand.
SP.L: Ile rather stay, then goe so: stop your Bowle.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: How now?

SP.SPEAKER: Bots.
SP.L: Is't Shroue-tuesday, that these Ghosts walke.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: What's your businesse, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Const.
SP.P: From the Duke: you are the man wee looke for, Signior, I haue Warrant here from the Duke, to apprehend you vpon fellony for robbing two Pedlers: I charge you i'th Dukes name goe quickly.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: Is the winde turn'd? well: this is that old Wolfe, my Father-in-law: seeke out your Mistris, Sirra.

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.L: Yes, Sir: as shafts by piecing are made strong,
So shall thy life be straightned by this wrong.

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes.
SP.L: In troth we are sorry.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: Braue men must bee crost, pish, it's but Fortunes Dice rouing against me: Come, sir, pray vse me like a Gen∣tleman, let me not be carried through the streets like a Pa∣geant.

SP.SPEAKER: Const.
SP.P: If these Gentlemen please, you shall goe along with them.

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes.
SP.L: Bee't so: come.

SP.SPEAKER: Const.
SP.L: What are you, sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Bots.
SP.P: I, sir? sometimes a figure, sometimes a cipher, as the State has occasion to cast vp her accounts: I'm a Soldier.

SP.SPEAKER: Const.
SP.L: Your name is Bots, is't not?

SP.SPEAKER: Bots.
SP.L: Bots is my name, Bots is knowne to this Company.

SP.SPEAKER: Const.
SP.L: I know you are, Sir: what's she?

SP.SPEAKER: Bots.
SP.L: A Gentlewoman, my Mother.

SP.SPEAKER: Const.
SP.L: Take em both along.

SP.SPEAKER: Bots.
SP.L: Me? Sirrr.

SP.SPEAKER: Billmen.
SP.L: And Sirrr.

SP.SPEAKER: Const.
SP.L: If he swagger, raise the street.

SP.SPEAKER: Bots.
SP.L: Gentlemen, Gentlemen, whither will you drag vs?

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: To the Garden house. Bots, are we euen with you?

SP.SPEAKER: Const.
SP.L: To Bridewell with em.

SP.SPEAKER: Bots.
SP.L: You will answer this.

SP.SPEAKER: Const.
SP.P: Better then a challenge, I haue warrant for my worke, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Wee'll goe before.

SP.SPEAKER: Const.
SP.L: Pray doe.
SP.P: Who, Signior Candido? a Cittizen of your degree consorted thus, and reuelling in such a house?

SP.SPEAKER: Cand.
SP.L: Why, sir? what house I pray?

SP.SPEAKER: Const.
SP.L: Lewd, and defamed.

SP.SPEAKER: Cand.
SP.L: Is't so? thankes, sir: I'm gone.

SP.SPEAKER: Const.
SP.L: What haue you there?

SP.SPEAKER: Cand.
SP.P: Lawnes which I bought, sir, of the Gentleman that keepes the house.

SP.SPEAKER: Const.
SP.P: And I haue warrant here, to search for such stolne Ware: these Lawnes are stolne.

SP.SPEAKER: Cand.
SP.L: Indeed!

SP.SPEAKER: Const.
SP.P: So he's the Thiefe, you the Receiuer: I'm sorry for this chance, I must commit you.

SP.SPEAKER: Cand.
SP.L: Me, sir, for what?

SP.SPEAKER: Const.
SP.P: These Goods are found vpon you, and you must answer't.

SP.SPEAKER: Cand.
SP.L: Must I so?

SP.SPEAKER: Const.
SP.L: Most certaine.

SP.SPEAKER: Cand.
SP.L: Ile send for Bayle.

SP.SPEAKER: Const.
SP.P: I dare not: yet because you are a Cittizen of worth, you shall not be made a pointing stocke, but without Guard passe onely with my selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Cand.
SP.L: To Bridewell too?

SP.SPEAKER: Const.
SP.L: No remedy.

SP.SPEAKER: Cand.
SP.P: Yes, patience: being not mad, they had mee once to Bedlam,
SP.L: Now I'm drawne to Bridewell, louing no Whores.

SP.SPEAKER: Const.
SP.L: You will buy Lawne?—
SP.STAGE: Enter at one doore Hipollito; at another, Lodouico, Astolfo, Carolo, Beraldo, Fontinell.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: Yonder's the Lord Hipollito, by any meanes leaue him and me together: Now will I turne him to a Madman.

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes.
SP.L: Saue you, my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: I ha strange newes to tell you.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: What are they?

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Your Mare's i'th pound.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: How's this?

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Your Nightingale is in a Limebush.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Ha?

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Your Puritanicall Honest Whore sits in a blue gowne.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Blue Gowne!

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: She'll chalke out your way to her now: she beats chalke.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Where, who dares?

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: Doe you know the Bricke-house of Castigation, by the Riuer side that runnes by Millan: the Schoole where they pronounce no letter well but O?

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: I know it not.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: Any man that has borne Office of Constable, or any woman that has falne from a Horse-load to a Cart-load, or like an old Hen that has had none but rotten egges in her nest, can direct you to her: there you shall see your Puncke amongst her back-friends, there you may haue her at your will, for there she beates Chalke, or grindes in the Mill, with a whip deedle, deedle, deedle, deedle; ah little monkey.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.P: What Rogue durst serue that Warrant, knowing I loued her?

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Some Worshipfull Rascall, I lay my life.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Ile beat the Lodgings downe about their eares
That are her Keepers.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: So you may bring an old house ouer her head.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Ile to her—
Ile to her, stood armed Fiends to guard the doores.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Oh me! what Monsters are men made by whores?
If this false fire doe Kindle him, there's one Faggot
More to the bonfire, now to my Bridewell Birds,
What Song will they sing?
SP.STAGE: Enter Duke, Carolo, Astolfo, Beraldo, Fontinell, three or foure Masters of Bridewell: Infaelice.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Your Bridewell? that the name? for beauty, strength,
Capacity and forme of ancient building,
(Besides the Riuers neighbourhood) few houses
Wherein we keepe our Court can better it.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Master.
SP.L: Hither from forraigne Courts haue Princes come,
And with our Duke did Acts of State Commence,
Here that great Cardinall had first audience,
(The graue Campayne,) that Duke dead, his Sonne
(That famous Prince) gaue free possession
Of this his Palace, to the Cittizens,
To be the poore mans ware-house: and endowed it
With Lands to'th valew of seuen hundred marke,
With all the bedding and the furniture, once proper
(As the Lands then were) to an Hospitall
Belonging to a Duke of Sauoy. Thus
Fortune can tosse the World, a Princes Court
Is thus a prison now.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: 'Tis Fortunes sport:
These changes common are: the Wheele of Fate
Turnes Kingdomes vp, till they fall desolate.
But how are these seuen hundred Markes by'th yeere
Imployde in this your Worke-house?

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Master.
SP.L: Warre and Peace
Feed both vpon those Lands: when the Iron doores
Of warres burst open, from this House are sent
Men furnisht in all Martiall Complement.
The Moone hath thorow her Bow scarce drawn to'th head,
(Like to twelue siluer Arrowes) all the Moneths,
Since 1600. Soldiers went aboord:
Here Prouidence and Charity play such parts,
The House is like a very Schoole of Arts,
For when our Soldiers (like Ships driuen from Sea,
With ribs all broken, and with tatterd sides,)
Cast anchor here agen, their ragged backes
How often doe we couer? that (like men)
They may be sent to their owne Homes agen.
All here are but one swarme of Bees, and striue
To bring with wearied thighs honey to the Hiue.
The sturdy Begger, and the lazy Lowne,
Gets here hard hands, or lac'd Correction.
The Vagabond growes stay'd, and learnes to 'bey,
The Drone is beaten well, and sent away
As other prisons are, (some for the Thiefe,
Some, by which vndone Credit gets reliefe
From bridled Debtors; others for the poore)
So this is for the Bawd, the Rogue, and Whore.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.L: An excellent Teeme of Horse.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Master.
SP.L: Nor is it seene,
That the whip drawes blood here, to coole the Spleene
Of any rugged Bencher: nor does offence
Feele smart, or spitefull, or rash euidence:
But pregnant testimony forth must stand,
Ere Iustice leaue them in the Beadles hand,
As Iron, on the Anuill are they laid,
Not to take blowes alone, but to be made
And fashioned to some Charitable vse.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.P: Thus wholsom'st Lawes spring from the worst abuse.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Let mercy touch your heart-strings (gracious Lord)
That it may sound like musike in the eare
Of a man desperate, (being i'th hands of Law.)

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: His name?

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Matheo.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: For a robbery? where is she?
SP.STAGE: Exit Bel. & one of the Masters of Bridewell.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: In this House.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Fetch you him hither—
Is this the Party?

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.P: This is the Hen, my Lord, that the Cocke (with the Lordly combe) your Sonne-in-law would crow ouer, and tread.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Are your two Seruants ready?

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.L: My two Pedlers are pack'd together, my good Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: 'Tis well: this day in Iudgement shall be spent,
Vice (like a wound launc'd) mends by punishment.

SP.SPEAKER: Infae.
SP.L: Let me be gone, my Lord, or stand vnseene;
'Tis rare when a Iudge strikes, and that none dye,
And 'tis vnfit then, women should be by.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Master.
SP.L: Wee'll place you, Lady, in some priuat roome.

SP.SPEAKER: Infae.
SP.L: Pray doe so.

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.L: Thus nice Dames sweare, it is vnfit their eyes
Sould view men caru'd vp for Anatomies,
Yet they'll see all, so they may stand vnseene,
Many women sure will sinne behind a Skreene.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Your Sonne (the Lord Hipollito) is entred.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Tell him we wish his presence. A word Storsa:
On what wings flew he hither?

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: These, I told him—his Larke whom he loued, was a Bridewell Bird, he's mad that this Cage should hold her, and is come to let her out.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: 'Tis excellent: away, goe call him hither.
SP.STAGE: Enter one of the Gouernours of the House, Bellafront after him with Matheo, after him the Constable. Enter at another doore, Lodouico and Hipollito: Orlando steps forth and brings in two Pedlers.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: You are to vs a stranger (worthy Lord)
'Tis strange to see you here.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: It is most fit,
That where the Sunne goes, Attomyes follow it.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Attomyes neither shape, nor honour beare:
Be you yourselfe, a Sunne-beame to shine cleare.
Is this the Gentleman? Stand forth & heare your accusation.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: Ile heare none: I flie hie in that: rather then Kites shall seize vpon me, and picke out mine eyes to my face, Ile strike my tallons thorow mine owne heart first, and spit my blood in theirs: I am here for shriuing those two fooles of their sinfull packe: when those Iack-dawes haue cawde o∣uer me, then must I cry guilty, or not guilty; the Law has worke enough already, and therefore Ile put no worke of mine into his hands, the Hangman shall ha't first, I did pluck those Ganders, did rob them.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: 'Tis well done to confesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: Confesse and be hanged, and then I flie hie, is't not so? that for that a gallowes is the worst rub that a good Bowler can meet with: I stumbled against such a post, else this night I had plaid the part of a true Sonne in these daies, vndone my Father-in-law, with him wud I ha run at leape∣frogge, and come ouer his gold, tho I had broke his necke for't: but the poore Salmon Trout is now in the Net.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: And now the Law must teach you to flie hie.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: Right, my Lord, and then may you flie low; no more words, a Mouse, Mum, you are stop'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Be good to my poore husband, deare my Lords.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: Asse, why shouldst thou pray them to be good to me, when no man here is good to one another?

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Did any hand worke in this theft but yours?

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: O, yes, my Lord, yes:—the Hangman has neuer one Sonne at a birth, his Children alwaies come by couples: Tho I cannot giue the old dog, my Father, a bone to gnaw, the Daughter shall bee sure of a Choke-peare.—Yes, my Lord, there was one more that fiddled my fine Pedlers, and that was my wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Alas, I?

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.L: O euerlasting, supernaturall superlatiue Villaine!

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes.
SP.L: Your wife, Matheo?

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Sure it cannot be.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: Oh, Sir, you loue no quarters of Mutton that hang vp, you loue none but whole Mutton; she set the robbery, I perform'd it; she spur'd me on, I gallop'd away.

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.L: My Lords.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: My Lords, (fellow giue me speach) if my poore life
may ransome thine, I yeeld it to the Law,
Thou hurt'st thy soule (yet wipest off no offence)
By casting blots vpon my Innocence:
Let not these spare me, but tell truth: no, see
Who slips his necke out of the misery,
Tho not out of the mischiefe: let thy Seruant
That shared in this base Act, accuse me here,
Why should my Husband perish, he goe cleare?

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.L: A god Child, hang thine owne Father.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Old fellow, was thy hand in too?

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.P: My hand was in the Pye, my Lord, I confesse it: my Mistris I see, will bring me to the Gallowes, and so leaue me; but Ile not leaue her so: I had rather hang in a womans com∣pany, then in a mans; because if weshould go to hell together, I should scarce be letten in, for all the Deuils are afraid to haue any women come amongst them, as I am true Thiefe, she neither consented to this fellony, nor knew of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: What fury prompts thee on to kill thy wife?

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: It's my humor, Sir, 'tis a foolish Bag-pipe that I make my selfe merry with: why should I eate hempe-seed at the Hangmans thirteene-pence halfe-penny Ordinary, and haue this whore laugh at me as I swing, as I totter?

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Is she a Whore?

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: A sixe-penny Mutton Pasty, for any to cut vp.

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.L: Ah, Toad, Toad, Toad.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: A Barbers Citterne for euery Seruingman to play vpon, that Lord, your Sonne, knowes it.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: I, sir, am I her Bawd then?

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: No, sir, but she's your Whore then,

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.L: Yea Spider, doest catch at great Flies?

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: My Whore?

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: I cannot talke, sir, and tell of your Reins, and your fees, and your whirligigs, and deuices: but, my Lord, I found em like Sparrowes in one nest, billing together, and bulling of me, I tooke em in bed, was ready to kill him was vp to stab her—

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Cloze thy ranke Iawes: pardon me, I am vexed,
Thou art a Villaine, a malicious Deuill,
Deepe as the place where thou art lost, thou lyest,
Since I am thus far got into this storme,
Ile thorow, and thou shalt see Ile thorow vntoucht.
When thou shalt perish in it.

SP.SPEAKER: Infae.
SP.L: 'Tis my cue
To enter now: roome, let my Prize be plaid,
I ha lurk'd in Cloudes, yet heard what all haue said,
What Iury more can proue, she has wrong'd my bed,
Then her owne husband, she must be punished;
I challenge Law, my Lord, Letters, and Gold, and Iewels
From my Lord that woman tooke.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Against that blacke-mouthed Deuill, against Letters, and Gold,
And against a iealous Wife I doe vphold,
Thus farre her reputation, I could sooner
Shake the Appenine, and crumble Rockes to dust,
Then (tho Ioues showre rayned downe) tempt her to lust.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: What shall I say?

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.P:
Say thou art not a Whore, and that's more then fifteene women (amongst fiue hundred) dare sweare with∣out lying: this shalt thou say, no let mee say't for thee; thy Husband's a Knaue, this Lord's an honest Man; thou art no Puncke, this Lady's a right Lady. Pacheco is a Thiefe as his Master is, but old Orlando is as true a man as thy Father is: I ha seene you flie hie, sir, & I ha seene you flie low, sir, and to keepe you from the Gallowes, sir, a blue Coat haue I worne, and a Thiefe did I turne, mine owne men are the Pedlers, my
twenty pound did flie hie, sir, your wiues Gowne did flie low, sir: whither flie you now, sir? you ha scap'd the Gal∣lowes, to the Deuill you flie next, sir. Am I right, my Liege?

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Your Father has the true Phisicion plaid.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: And I am now his Patient.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.P: And be so still, 'tis a good signe when our cheekes blush at ill.

SP.SPEAKER: Const.
SP.L: The Linnen Draper (Signior Candido)
He whom the Citty tearmes the Patient man,
Is likewise here for buying of those Lawnes
The Pedlers lost.

SP.SPEAKER: Infae.
SP.L: Alas good Candido.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Fetch him: and when these payments vp are cast,
Weigh out your light Gold, but let's haue them last.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: In Bridewell, Candido?

SP.SPEAKER: Cand.
SP.L: Yes, my good Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: What make you here?

SP.SPEAKER: Cand.
SP.L: My Lord, what make you here?

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: I'm here to saue right, and to driue wrong hence.

SP.SPEAKER: Cand.
SP.L: And I to beare wrong here with patience.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: You ha bought stolne Goods.

SP.SPEAKER: Cand.
SP.L: So they doe say, my Lord,
Yet bought I them vpon a Gentlemans word,
And I magine now, as I thought then,
That there be Theeues, but no Theeues Gentlemen.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Your Credit's crack'd being here.

SP.SPEAKER: Cand.
SP.L: No more then Gold
Being crack'd which does his estimation hold.
I was in Bedlam once, but was I mad?
They made me pledge Whores healths, but am I bad,
Because I'm with bad people?

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Well, stand by,
If you take wrong, wee'll cure the iniurry.
SP.STAGE: Enter Constable, after them Bots, after him two Beadles, one with Hempe, the other with a Beetle.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Stay, stay, what's he? a prisoner?

SP.SPEAKER: Const.
SP.L: Yes, my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: He seemes a Soldier?

SP.SPEAKER: Bots.
SP.P: I am what I seeme, Sir, one of Fortunes Bastards, a Soldier, and a Gentleman, and am brought in here with Master Constables band of Bilmen, because they face mee downe that I liue (like those that keepe Bowling-alleyes) by the sinnes of the people, in being a Squire of the body.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Oh, an Apple-squire.

SP.SPEAKER: Bots.
SP.P: Yes, sir, that degree of scuruy Squiers, and that I am maintained by the best part that is commonly in a woman, by the worst players of those parts, but I am knowne to all this company.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: My Lord, 'tis true, we all know him, 'tis Lieutenant Bots.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Bots, and where ha you serued, Bots?

SP.SPEAKER: Bots.
SP.P: In most of your hottest Seruices in the Low-coun∣tries: at the Groyne I was wounded in this thigh, and halted vpon't, but 'tis now sound. In Cleueland I mist but little, hauing the bridge of my nose broken downe with two great stones, as I was scaling a Fort: I ha beene tryed, Sir, too, in Gelderland, and scap'd hardly there from being blown vp at a Breach: I was fired, and lay i'th Surgeons hands for't, till the fall of the leafe following.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: All this may be, and yet you no Soldier.

SP.SPEAKER: Bots.
SP.P: No Soldier, sir? I hope these are Seruices that your proudest Commanders doe venture vpon, and neuer come off sometimes.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Well, sir, because you say you are a Soldier,
Ile vse you like a Gentleman: make roome there,
Plant him amongst you, we shall haue anon
Strange Hawkes flie here before vs: if none light on you,
You shall with freedome take your flight:
But if you proue a Bird of baser wing,
Wee'll vse you like such Birds, here you shall sing.

SP.SPEAKER: Bots.
SP.L: I wish to be tried at no other weapon.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Why, is he furnisht with those in pyments?

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Master.
SP.L: The Pander is more dangerous to a State,
Then is the common Thiefe, and tho our lawes
Lie heauier on the Thiefe, yet that the Pander
May know the Hangmans ruffe should fit him too,
Therefore he's set to beat Hempe.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: This does sauour
Of Iustice, basest Slaues to basest labour.
Now pray, set open Hell, and let vs see
The Shee-Deuils that are here.

SP.SPEAKER: Infa.
SP.L: Me thinkes this place
Should make euen Lais honest.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Master.
SP.L: Some it turnes good,
But (as some men whose hands are once in blood,
Doe in a pride spill more) so, some going hence,
Are (by being here) lost in more impudence:
Let it not to them (when they come) appeare,
That any one does as their Iudge sit here:
But that as Gentlemen you come to see,
And then perhaps their tongues will walke more free.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Let them be marshall'd in: be couerd all,
Fellowes, now to make the Sceane more Comicall.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.L: Will not you be smelt out, Bots.

SP.SPEAKER: Bots.
SP.L: No, your brauest whores haue the worst noses.
SP.STAGE: Enter two of the Masters: a Constable after them, then Dorathe Target, braue, after her two Beadles, th'one with a wheele, the other with a blue Gowne.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Are not you a Bride, forsooth?

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.L: Say yee?

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.L: He wud know if these be not your Bridemen.

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.P:
Vuh, yes, sir: and looke yee, doe you see the Bride-laces that I giue at my wedding, will serue to tye Rosemary
to both your Coffins when you come from hanging-Scab▪

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.L: Fie, Puncke, fie, fie, fie.

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.P: Out you stale stinking head of Garlicke, foh, at my heeles.

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.L: My head's clouen.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: O, let the Gentlewoman alone, she's going to shrift.

SP.SPEAKER: Ast.
SP.L: Nay to doe penance.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.L: I, I, goe Puncke, goe to the Crosse and be whipt.

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.P: Mary mew, mary muffe, mary hang you goodman Dog: whipt? doe yee take me for a base Spittle whore? in troth Gentlemen, you weare the cloathes of Gentlemen, but you carry not the mindes of Gentlemen, to abuse a Gentle∣woman of my fashion.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Fashion? pox a your fashions, art not a whore?

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.L: Goodman Slaue.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: O fie, abuse her not, let vs two talke,
What mought I call your name, pray?

SP.SPEAKER: Cor.
SP.P: I'm not ashamed of my name, Sir, my name is Mistris Doll Target, a Westerne Gentlewoman.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Her Target against any Pike in Millan.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Why is this wheele borne after her?

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Master.
SP.L: She must spinne.

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.L: A coorse thred it shall be, as all threds are.

SP.SPEAKER: Ast.
SP.L: If you spin, then you'll earne money here too?

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.P: I had rather get halfe a Crowne abroad, then ten Crownes here.

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.L: Abroad? I thinke so.

SP.SPEAKER: Infae.
SP.L: Doest thou not weepe now thou art here?

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.P: Say yee? weepe? yes forsooth, as you did when you lost your Maidenhead: doe you not heare how I weep?

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Farewell Doll.

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.L: Farewell Dog.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Past shame: past penitence, why is that blue Gowne?

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Master.
SP.L: Being stript out of her wanton loose attire,
That Garment she puts on, base to the eye,
Onely to cloath her in humility.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Are all the rest like this?

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Master.
SP.L: No, my good Lord.
You see, this Drab swells with a wanton reyne,
The next that enters has a different straine.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Variety is good, let's see the rest.

SP.SPEAKER: Bots.
SP.L: Your Grace sees I'm sound yet, & no Bullets hit me.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Come off so, and 'tis well.

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes.
SP.L: Here's the second Messe.
SP.STAGE: Enter the two Masters, after them the Constable, after him Penelope Whore-hound, like a Cittizens wife, after her two Beadles, one with a blue Gowne, another with Chalke and a Mallet.

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.P: I'ha worne many a costly Gowne, but I was neuer thus guarded with blue Coats, and Beadles, and Constables, and—

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.L: Alas faire Mistris, spoyle not thus your eyes.

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.P: Oh sweet sir, I feare the spoyling of other places a∣bout me that are dearer then my eyes; if you be Gentlemen, if you be men, or euer came of a woman, pitty my case, stand to me, sticke to me, good sir, you are an old man.

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.P: Hang not on me, I prethee, old Trees beare no such fruit.

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.L: Will you bayle me, Gentlemen?

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Bayle thee, art in for debt?

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.P: No—is my Iudge, sir, I am in for no debts, I payd my Taylor for this Gowne, the last fiue shillings a weeke that was behind, yesterday.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: What is your name, I pray?

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.P: Penelope Whore-hound, I come of the Whore-hounds. How does Lieutenant Bots.

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes.
SP.L: A ha Bots.

SP.SPEAKER: Bots.
SP.L: A very honest woman, as I'm a Soldier, a pox Bots ye.

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.P:
I was neuer in this pickle before, and yet if I goe a∣mongst Cittizens wiues, they ieere at me: if I goe among the Loose-bodied Gownes, they cry a pox on me, because I goe ciuilly attyred, and sweare their trade was a good
trade, till such as I am tooke it out of their hands: good Lieutenant Bots, speake to these Captaines to bayle me.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Master.
SP.P: Begging for bayle still? you are a trim gossip, goe giue her the blue Gowne, set her to her chare, worke Hus∣wife, for your bread, away.

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.P: Out you Dog, a pox on you all, women are borne to curse thee, but I shall liue to see twenty such flat-caps sha∣king Dice for a penny-worth of Pippins: out, you blue-eyed Rogue.

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes.
SP.L: Ha, ha, ha.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Euen now she wept, and praid, now does she curse?

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Master.
SP.P: Seeing me: if still she had staid, this had beene worse.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Was she euer here before?

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Master.
SP.L: Fiue times at least,
And thus if men come to her, haue her eyes wrung, and
wept out her bayle.

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes.
SP.L: Bots, you know her?

SP.SPEAKER: Bots.
SP.L: Is there any Gentleman here, that knowes not a
Whore, and is he a haire the worse for that?

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Is she a Citty-dame, she's so attyred?

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Master.
SP.L: No, my good Lord, that's onely but the vaile
To her loose body, I haue seene her here
In gayer Masking Suits, as seuerall Sawces
Giue one Dish seuerall Tastes, so change of Habits
In Whores is a bewitching Art: to day she's all in
Colours to besot Gallants, then in modest blacke,
To catch the Cittizen, and this from their Examinations
Drawne, now shall you see a Monster both in shape
And nature quite from these, that sheds no teare,
Nor yet is nice, 'tis a plaine ramping Beare,
Many such Whales are cast vpon this Shore.

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes.
SP.L: Let's see her.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Master.
SP.L: Then behold a swaggering Whore.

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.L: Keep your grownd, Bots.

SP.SPEAKER: Bots.
SP.P: I doe but trauerse to spy aduantage how to arme my selfe.
SP.STAGE: Enter the two Masters first, after them the Constable, after them a Beadle beating a Bason, then Catyryna Bountinall, with Mistris Horsleach, after them another Beadle with a blue head guarded with yellow.

SP.SPEAKER: Cat.
SP.P: Sirra, when I cry hold your hands, hold, you Rogue-Catcher, hold: Bawd, are the French Chilblaines in your heeles, that you can come no faster? are not you (Bawd) a Whores Ancient, and must not I follow my Colours?

SP.SPEAKER: Hors.
SP.P: O Mistris Katherine, you doe me wrong to accuse mee here as you doe, before the right Worshipfull: I am knowne for a motherly honest woman, and no Bawd.

SP.SPEAKER: Cat.
SP.P: Mary foh, honest? burnt at fourteene, seuen times whipt, sixe times carted, nine times duck'd, search'd by some hundred and fifty Constables, and yet you are honest? Honest Mistris Horsleach, is this World, a World to keepe Bawds and Whores honest? How many times hast thou giuen Gentlemen a quart of wine in a gallon pot? how ma∣ny twelue-penny Fees, nay two shillings Fees, nay, when any Embassadours ha beene here, how many halfe crowne Fees hast thou taken? how many Carriers hast thou bribed for Country Wenches? how often haue I rinst your lungs in Aquauitae, and yet you are honest?

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: And what were you the whilest?

SP.SPEAKER: Cat.
SP.P: Mary hang you, Master Slaue, who made you an examiner?

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Well said, belike this Deuill spares no man.

SP.SPEAKER: Cat.
SP.L: What art thou prethee?

SP.SPEAKER: Bots.
SP.L: Nay what art thou prethee?

SP.SPEAKER: Cat.
SP.L: A Whore, art thou a Thiefe?

SP.SPEAKER: Bots.
SP.P: A Thiefe, no, I defie the calling, I am a Soldier, haue borne Armes in the Field, beene in many a hot Skyr∣mish, yet come off sound.

SP.SPEAKER: Cat.
SP.P:
Sound with a pox to yee, yee abominable Rogue! you a Soldier? you in Skirmishes? where? amongst pottle pots in a Bawdy-house? Looke, looke here, you Madam
Wormeaten, doe not you know him?

SP.SPEAKER: Hors.
SP.P: Lieutenant Bots, where haue yee beene this many a day?

SP.SPEAKER: Bots.
SP.P: Old Bawd, doe not discredit me, seeme not to know me.

SP.SPEAKER: Hors.
SP.P: Not to know yee, Master Bots? as long as I haue breath, I cannot forget thy sweet face.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.P: Why, doe you know him? he saies he is a Sol∣dier.

SP.SPEAKER: Cat.
SP.P: He a Soldier? a Pander, a Dog that will licke vp sixe pence: doe yee heare, you Master Swines snout, how long is't since you held the doore for me, and cried too't agen, no body comes, yee Rogue you?

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes.
SP.L: Ha, ha, ha, y'are smelt out agen, Bots.

SP.SPEAKER: Bots.
SP.P: Pox ruyne her nose for't, and I be not reuenged for this—vm yee Bitch.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: Dee yee heare yee Madam? why does your Ladiship swagger thus? y'are very braue, me thinkes.

SP.SPEAKER: Cat.
SP.L: Not at your cost, Master Cods-head,
Is any man here bleare-eyed to see me braue?

SP.SPEAKER: Ast.
SP.L: Yes, I am,
Because good Cloathes vpon a Whores backe
Is like faire painting vpon a rotten wall.

SP.SPEAKER: Cat.
SP.P: Mary muffe Master Whoremaster, you come vpon me with sentences.

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.L: By this light has small sence for't.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: O fie, fie, doe not vex her.
And yet me thinkes a creature of more scuruy conditions
Should not know what a good Petticoate were.

SP.SPEAKER: Cat.
SP.L: Mary come out,
SP.P: Y'are so busie about my Petticoate, you'll creepe vp to my placket, and yee cood but attaine the honour, but and the outsides offend your Rogueships, looke o'the lining, 'tis Silke.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Is't Silke 'tis lined with then?

SP.SPEAKER: Cat.
SP.P:
Silke? I Silke, Master Slaue, you wud bee glad to wipe your nose with the skirt on't: this 'tis to come a∣mong
a company of Cods-heads that know not how to vse a Gentlewoman.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Tell her the Duke is here.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Master.
SP.L: Be modest, Kata, the Duke is here.

SP.SPEAKER: Cat.
SP.P: If the Deuill were here, I care not: set forward, yee Rogues, and giue attendance according to your places, let Bawds and Whores be sad, for Ile sing and the Deuill were a dying.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Why before her does the Bason ring?

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Master.
SP.L: It is an emblem of their reuelling,
The whips we vse lets forth their wanton blood,
Making them calme, and more to calme their pride,
In stead of Coaches they in Carts doe ride.
Will your Grace see more of this bad Ware?

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: No, shut vp shop, wee'll now breake vp the faire,
Yet ere we part—you, sir, that take vpon yee
The name of Soldier, that true name of worth,
Which, action not vaine boasting best sets forth,
To let you know how farre a Soldiers name
Stands from your title, and to let you see,
Soldiers must not be wrong'd where Princes be:
This bee your sentence.

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes.
SP.L: Defend your selfe, Bots.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: First, all the priuat sufferance that the house
Inflicts vpon Offenders, you (as the basest)
Shall vndergoe it double, after which
You shall bee whipt, sir, round about the Citty,
Then banisht from the Land.

SP.SPEAKER: Bots.
SP.L: Beseech your Grace.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Away with him, see it done, Panders and Whores
Are Citty-plagues, which being kept aliue,
Nothing that lookes like goodnes ere can thriue.
Now good Orlando, what say you to your bad Sonne-in-law▪

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.P: Mary this, my Lord, he is my Sonne-in-law, and in law will I be his Father: for if law can pepper him, he shall be so parboild, that he shall stinke no more i'th nose of the Common-wealth.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Be yet more kinde and mercifull, good Father.

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.P: Doest thou beg for him, thou precious mans meat, thou? has he not beaten thee, kickt thee, trod on thee, and doest thou fawne on him like his Spanniell? has hee not pawnd thee to thy Petticoate, sold thee to thy smock, made yee leape at a crust, yet woodst haue me saue him?

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Oh yes, good sir, women shall learne of me,
To loue their husbands in greatest misery,
Then shew him pitty, or you wracke my selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Orl.
SP.P: Haue yee eaten Pigeons that y'are so kinde-hearted to your Mate? Nay, y'are a couple of wilde Beares, Ile haue yee both baited at one stake: but as for this Knaue, the Gallowes is thy due, and the Gallowes thou shalt haue, Ile haue iustice of the Duke, the Law shall haue thy life, what, doest thou hold him? let goe his hand: if thou doest not for∣sake him, a Fathers euerlasting blessing fall vpon both your heads: away, goe, kisse out of my sight, play thou the Whore no more, nor thou the Thiefe agen, my house shall be thine, my meate shall be thine, and so shall my wine, but my money shall bee mine, and yet when I die, (so thou doest not flie hie) take all, yet good Matheo, mend.
SP.L: Thus for ioy weepes Orlando, and doth end.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Then heare, Matheo: all your woes are stayed
By your good Father-in-law: all your Ills
Are cleare purged from you by his working pills.
Come Signior Candido, these greene yong wits
(We see by Circumstance) this plot hath laid,
Still to prouoke thy patience, which they finde
A wall of Brasse, no Armour's like the minde;
Thou hast taught the Citty patience, now our Court
Shall be thy Spheare, where from thy good report,
Rumours this truth vnto the world shal sing,
A Patient man's a Patterne for a King.
